posts.title: Minnetonka Moccasin Resole
posts.markdown:
>For increased durability & ground feel, and as a replacement for the shitty standard Minnetonka soles. Should work with any leather bottomed moccasin. ####Sources For dealing with the [old soles & clean up](http://adventure.howstuffworks.com/outdoor-activities/hiking/how-to-make-and-repair-camping-equipment3.htm) For the [gluing process & clamping advice](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/huaraches/ecOaQH7yK-Q) A walkthrough of a [similar resole on climbing shoes](http://www.rockclimbing.com/forum/Climbing_Information_C2/Gear_Heads_F40/Quarter_Sole_-_Resole_Step-by-Step_P2513301/)
If you are looking for other resources, I found that articles on resoling climbing shoes, hiking boots, and making huaraches were the most helpful. ________ ###Supplies ________ + 6mm Vibram Cherry sheet or selected soles + Shears + Box cutter + Plywood + Saw to make the clamping rigs + Clamps + Wire Brush and/or Coarse Sandpaper + Razor Blade or other sharp, disposable "scraper" + Acetone + Disposable Paint Brush + Barge Cement (2 Tubes) + Shoe Goo + Car + Towels + Rubber Mallet or Hammer _____ ###Day 1: Preparation _____ ####Remove the old soles Use the box cutter to cut the sewn-in thread, or unglue w/ heat. I was dealing with [these](http://www.minnetonkamoccasin.com/Products/Detail/classic-moc) moccasins with a typical "sewn-in" sole as opposed to one that is glued on. I am unsure about dealing with glued on soles and what the process for those would be. The entire reason behind this project is that my soles had worn down over 6 months, enough to break the thread which unraveled the entire sole from the bottom of the shoe. ####Examine old soles & determine replacements Consider thickness, and tread. I suggest you go with a sheet of vibram rubber, because you can cut the new soles in a perfect outline of the old. Ready-made soles may not match. I used a sheet of 6mm Vibram "Cherry" from [DIY Footwear](http://www.diyfootwear.com/vibram-cherry-6mm/). ####Make shoe clamps Two small pieces of plywood on either side of one clamp. You will need either two or four of these rigs. Two if you want to clamp the shoes together and you dont have more than two clamps, like me. Four if you are thorough and neat. > This and the car method of pressure will do a number on the leather if it seems fragile. You have been warned. ----- ### Day 2: Resoling ___________ ####Cut out replacement soles Trace your old soles onto the sheet of rubber. Take care so that you do not end up with two right soles like me!
Luckily for you, my mistake shows the ability of these methods of resoling to last, even with the bumpy, treaded side connected to the leather. Obviously, you want the flat, non-treaded side connected with the moccasin. ####Clean moccasin bottoms Remove all debris. The first step to success is making the bottoms surgically clean. I used a combination of GooGone, a razor blade, a wire brush and sandpaper to make this happen. After this, if the bottoms are not already suede, brush them into suede with the wire brush. Give the bottoms a final, hard cleaning with wire brush repeatedly dipped in acetone. Use it very librally, you want the soles to be a bit damp when you glue them. The reason for acetone is that the new Barge Cement formula now lacks a certain ingredient & the acetone works to counteract this lack, making the bond stronger all while making the soles cleaner. Something about ketones. >####While wet with solvent and with good ventilation: ####Apply cement to moc bottom and new sole, spread carefully and evenly with brush Emphasis on carefully, the glue dries a translucent yellowy white. If you get it all over the sides of your moccassins, they will literally look like you smeared boogers all over them. ####Wait 5 minutes & apply second coat on both
####Wait 5 minutes & apply third liberal coat to only moc bottoms on the heels and toes
####Wait 20 minutes for tackiness & align soles with bottoms and stick together. Please be advised you will only be able to do this once, there is little to no readjusting after you have touched them together. ####Put towel over each shoe & beat with hammer/mallet (Bottom and top) Special attention to heels and toes. This will help solidify the bond so the soles do not move whatsoever during the pressure applied over the next day. One of the links in the sources section says to "beat the hell out of them." Don't hold back! ####Lay towels over the shoes and place under back tires of your car. Alternatively, you can make a shoemaker’s anvil or jury rig a clamping structure that allows for heavy, even distribution of pressure. I chose the car.
Back over the shoes so that they are covered (most importantly in the heel and middle). Please use towels to cover the shoes, and leave for 12 hrs. Remember, you are looking for heavy, even pressure. ____ ###Day 3: Final Touches _______ Take out from under car, clamp heels and toes of the shoes separately between your makeshift clamping rigs for another 12 hrs. After that, they are free to be worn.
Reformation will take place over the next couple days of wear, seal any gaps that may form during this period between moc and sole with Shoe Goo. Gaps will usually form from inaccurate sole cuts or gluing, where the sole is bent up the side of the moc during wear. If you aligned the soles perfectly and applied an adiquiate amount of glue and pressure, then you should not have to do this. If you have a belt sander or Dremel handy, then use this to smooth out the edges of the soles and any innacuracies in placement.
posts.html:
For increased durability & ground feel, and as a replacement for the shitty standard Minnetonka soles. Should work with any leather bottomed moccasin.

Sources

For dealing with the old soles & clean up
For the gluing process & clamping advice
A walkthrough of a similar resole on climbing shoes


If you are looking for other resources, I found that articles on resoling climbing shoes, hiking boots, and making huaraches were the most helpful.

Supplies

  • 6mm Vibram Cherry sheet or selected soles
  • Shears
  • Box cutter
  • Plywood + Saw to make the clamping rigs
  • Clamps
  • Wire Brush and/or Coarse Sandpaper
  • Razor Blade or other sharp, disposable "scraper"
  • Acetone
  • Disposable Paint Brush
  • Barge Cement (2 Tubes)
  • Shoe Goo
  • Car
  • Towels
  • Rubber Mallet or Hammer

Day 1: Preparation

Remove the old soles

Use the box cutter to cut the sewn-in thread, or unglue w/ heat. I was dealing with these moccasins with a typical "sewn-in" sole as opposed to one that is glued on. I am unsure about dealing with glued on soles and what the process for those would be. The entire reason behind this project is that my soles had worn down over 6 months, enough to break the thread which unraveled the entire sole from the bottom of the shoe.

Examine old soles & determine replacements

Consider thickness, and tread. I suggest you go with a sheet of vibram rubber, because you can cut the new soles in a perfect outline of the old. Ready-made soles may not match. I used a sheet of 6mm Vibram "Cherry" from DIY Footwear.

Make shoe clamps

Two small pieces of plywood on either side of one clamp. You will need either two or four of these rigs. Two if you want to clamp the shoes together and you dont have more than two clamps, like me. Four if you are thorough and neat.

This and the car method of pressure will do a number on the leather if it seems fragile. You have been warned.

Day 2: Resoling

Cut out replacement soles

Trace your old soles onto the sheet of rubber. Take care so that you do not end up with two right soles like me!


Luckily for you, my mistake shows the ability of these methods of resoling to last, even with the bumpy, treaded side connected to the leather. Obviously, you want the flat, non-treaded side connected with the moccasin.

Clean moccasin bottoms

Remove all debris. The first step to success is making the bottoms surgically clean. I used a combination of GooGone, a razor blade, a wire brush and sandpaper to make this happen. After this, if the bottoms are not already suede, brush them into suede with the wire brush. Give the bottoms a final, hard cleaning with wire brush repeatedly dipped in acetone. Use it very librally, you want the soles to be a bit damp when you glue them. The reason for acetone is that the new Barge Cement formula now lacks a certain ingredient & the acetone works to counteract this lack, making the bond stronger all while making the soles cleaner. Something about ketones.

While wet with solvent and with good ventilation:

Apply cement to moc bottom and new sole, spread carefully and evenly with brush

Emphasis on carefully, the glue dries a translucent yellowy white. If you get it all over the sides of your moccassins, they will literally look like you smeared boogers all over them.

Wait 5 minutes & apply second coat on both


Wait 5 minutes & apply third liberal coat to only moc bottoms on the heels and toes


Wait 20 minutes for tackiness & align soles with bottoms and stick together.

Please be advised you will only be able to do this once, there is little to no readjusting after you have touched them together.

Put towel over each shoe & beat with hammer/mallet (Bottom and top)

Special attention to heels and toes. This will help solidify the bond so the soles do not move whatsoever during the pressure applied over the next day. One of the links in the sources section says to "beat the hell out of them." Don't hold back!

Lay towels over the shoes and place under back tires of your car.

Alternatively, you can make a shoemaker’s anvil or jury rig a clamping structure that allows for heavy, even distribution of pressure. I chose the car.


Back over the shoes so that they are covered (most importantly in the heel and middle). Please use towels to cover the shoes, and leave for 12 hrs. Remember, you are looking for heavy, even pressure.

Day 3: Final Touches

Take out from under car, clamp heels and toes of the shoes separately between your makeshift clamping rigs for another 12 hrs. After that, they are free to be worn.

Reformation will take place over the next couple days of wear, seal any gaps that may form during this period between moc and sole with Shoe Goo. Gaps will usually form from inaccurate sole cuts or gluing, where the sole is bent up the side of the moc during wear. If you aligned the soles perfectly and applied an adiquiate amount of glue and pressure, then you should not have to do this. If you have a belt sander or Dremel handy, then use this to smooth out the edges of the soles and any innacuracies in placement.

posts.title: Skillgenie 1 - Summer 2014
posts.markdown:
Diarist is a web app that deals with learning curves. The idea was essentially spurred by the video below.

THE GAP by Ira Glass from frohlocke on Vimeo.

____ Glass says, "Your taste is good enough that you can tell that what you're making is kind of a disappointment to you... Alot of people never get past that phase, alot of people at that point they quit." He goes on to say that in order to bridge that gap, between your taste and production, you must struggle through "a large volume of work". I applaud him for making this insight, but what can be said of this gap and the struggle? What keeps people from quitting? Glass has made us aware of the gap, but how does one overcome it? There is truth in him saying, "by moving through a large volume of work". At a certain point, rote repitition is the only way to move past certain artistic blocks. For instance, when a person learning the guitar cannot switch chords fast enough; repition works especially well for physical limitation. This is well represented in sports, but the question remains: what if you have no coach. How does one sucessfully engage in independant practice without a stable source of knowledge? Repitition of disappointing work with little growth is literally the fast-track to becoming a sub-par artist. So when Ira asks us to produce a large volume of work, I say what work? How does one keep from perpetually disappointing themselves? Glass gives us awareness of the gap, and we have established that "practice makes perfect", but before anything, one must be able to choose the right work. This barrier to knowing the what and how and why of a subject is commonly referred to as a learning curve and is what Diarist seeks to remedy. ####Awareness of the gap is only the very first step to overcoming it. By blending small, diary style posting with a guide-esqe, expository assembly of the individual posts by the Diarist app, I hope to create courage in the face of this gap. I imaging the user's hands trembling, half in fear and half in excitement when they enter their "diary" name. A question, not impossible, but one that seems insurmountable. Users with no programming experience could enter "I want to publish an iOS App" or people with questionable writing could say, "How to write a novel" and they could trust in the Diarist community and the app itself to guide them. The wealth of information created by the community of Diarists could take care of the specifics pertaining to each subject, but the application itself could provide a framework, incentive and a set of general beginning materials. Suggestions for sub-goals or "chapters" could be auto-suggested by the app, pulling from other diarys. However the only way to test this method of overcoming learning curves and to hone it is to take part in it myself. I will keep a daily journal on the development of this app beginning with the question: How do I create & publish a web application? With my first "chapter" as: App Flow & Prelimiary Research and second as: Web App Architecture & MEAN. ____ 6/13 Friday - Preliminary Research The Importance of Habit
Insight:
When one does something alot within the confines of a habit loop, they learn to like it, they gain pleasure from it. They gain pleasure from the fufillment of the craving.

Resources:
The Power of Habit - Charles Duhigg
6/14 Saturday - Preliminary Research Definitions of Learning Curves
Insight:
Learning curves are often exponential followed by a plateau. Habit and persistance are the driving forces behind the growth, the plateau afterword must be addressed but can be ignored for now, since we are focusing primarily on the struggle that comes with the initial curve. The struggle behind this "steep" curve can be identified as having to do with both the seeming insurmountablilty of the goal and the blistering, pummelling pace at which the initial learning comes. Refer to the x,y graph on the wiki resource.

Resources:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_curve
___ 6/15 Sunday - Preliminary Research Keystone Habits
Insight:
Duhigg refers to habits that lead to change in other aspects of life, or as catalysts for more positive actions: Keystone habits. He writes that these pillars of the habit world cause "small wins" and "allow other habits to flourish by [architecting] new structures." As this pertains to Diarist, we want this once-a-day journaling to be the keystone habit for the goal or process or skill that the user wants to attain. It would not directly cause it but rather follow like this: A man wants to be a blues guitarist, so the writing would help him (this is the part that the keystone habit causes ->>) anaylze his progress and push him to continue, both emotionally & subject-wise. As for when to record, when to write, the interface needs to be as easy to open as TextEdit. I often record when I feel a "spark", or an interesting instance where the resource connects with my subject (particularly a preexisting question). I write when I can quite literreally feel the connections form in my brain, these "coherent & exciting moments of mental and physical inspiration"

Resources:
The Power of Habit - Charles Duhigg
____ 6/16 Monday - Preliminary Research On Habits & Specific Rules B.J. Fogg on Habits https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AdKUJxjn-R8 This talk was really great, it offered new views on habit other than Duhigg's loops which I sorely need. It also points out many of the traditional problems with methods of changing habits. He begins with a description of a small change and reward. To me, a rediculously small change and a silly reward. I do not know whether or not this common troupe in the global habit change discussion is purely used to illustrate a point or whether a man that teaches at Stanford really believes that minute increments and pats on the back are really the way to go. He claims, like Duhigg, that using motivation and sheer willpower as "cues" and "rewards" is a losing strategy. I do not entirely disagree, but both of these things are nessicary for the long haul, as motivators of change. Maybe Fogg can transition from the rediculousness of doing pushups after he uses the toilet. Habits may be somewhat systematic and need to be made automatic, but they are also organic and require a certain grace to execute. I cannot justify a routine if the cue and reward are meaningless. When Fogg begins to talk about Weight Loss and the myriad of associated habits or behaviors that must be changed in order to lose weight, he touches on Diarist "chapters". Small wins must fall between the chapters as they act as big wins. Weight Loss is the question we want you to ask, and the chapters are the many steps to get there. He mentions stress reduction, diet and excerise to name a few. Baby steps with grace & meaning limit the amount of backsliding that may happen. You come to Diarist with the motivation, and we help you overcome the gap in ability. Not specifically, but by setting up a structure that allows you to do it yourself and will limit chance for failure, burnout & all other associated pitfalls. The structure most importantly supports and increases motivation. Although, rewards may be backsliding. 6 days and a cheat day. This is what a cue is comprised of, and Fogg hits this right on the head: adiquite motivation, ability & a trigger. More of the specifics of his model can be found at: http://www.behaviormodel.org/index.html In the case of "tiny habits" as Fogg presents them, he says much like Duhigg: using existing cues and replacing the routine works. Fogg suggests replacing the already small routine with a yet smaller one, increasing the likeliness that we will do it according to his motivation vs. skill chart. Back to Duhigg: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=voX0gUn_JOI He shines a light on the extrinsic means for the internal reward. At first, he says, cues and rewards must be external enough to trick the brain. Eventually they may fade into internal feelings in liu of the external reward which once provided those feelings. He also goes into depth about the mechanics of habits of the individual and how groups support them emotionally. He says that intellectually we may be able to tell that we can change, but groups are important in moments of weakness. AT 22:00 he talks about food journaling and how the process and repitition of documenting a process can lead you to avoidence of mistakes and progress. They learn their own patterns. Avoiding stupidity rather than being brilliant - Charlie Munger. He points out that willpower is easily taxed. Willpower is not used when actions are habitualized. ____ 6/17 Tuesday - Preliminary Research Motivation & Habits Specifics http://blog.greatcodeclub.com/learn-new-things/ A great blog & resource to help developers take on side projects. A few great quotes here: >"However, my goal was never to learn how programming languages work. My goal was to create one, so I had to learn. I think this is very important. Learning for the sake of learning never worked for me, but learning because I wanted to do something with that knowledge did." This post comes close to the proposed Diarist way of small wins journaling. The rules at the end are indespensable too. Yesterday, I remember an important thing that I forgot to write down. A habit for around a month usually cements it. Two rules what have helped me are: ones from Leo Babatua "Make it a rule never to skip two days in a row." and one from freshman English 101, "always allows yourself to spew a 'shitty first draft'", editing on-the-go restricts the flow of ideas. These really have to do with both the app itself (what it gives to the user) and the flow (the meta, what the app is trying to achieve) Babauta's list on his blog Zen Habits is a great summary of all the things I have discussed or in some capacity learned so far. http://zenhabits.net/top-20-motivation-hacks-4/ I felt good knowing that I could still learn from each of the points without seeing them as something completely new. It seems that what is coming soon is application of these points about habits and its processes into an app flow. Then, before learning MEAN & web app architechture I need to validate my idea with actual users. A great place to look for further info would be Tim Ferriss & his books. As inspired by his "Day In the Life Of..." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pV2hLYqRnvY. 6/18 Wednesday - Preliminary Research Clean-Up, Learning Curves & RAS Did a little resource hunting today and transferring of ideas from numerous text edit files to this blog. Kaufmen debunks the 10,000 hour rule. Found this to be encouraging. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5MgBikgcWnY At 8:00 he talks about learning curves. Gives a great graph. Reinforces what I have learned so far, which is great because I know that I am on the right track. He says it takes 20 hours to break the curve, via rapid skill aquisition . More definitley needs to be looked at on this topic. Tim Ferriss would be great. MAGICAL words after 10:00. ____ 6/19 Thursday - Preliminary Research Began Start Small, Stay Small by Walling. He avoids the venture-capital buisness-y startup lingo and communicates from a developers POV which is good. He stresses niche market, which I have read time and time again. I will need to target Diarist at a specific group. This can happen with the subjects. If we start the community with say, health and fitness/barefoot runners (super specific) and electronic music producers? Were going out "two or three descriptors" black barefoot runners, dubstep edm producers, ect... After reading, I should probably fill in this sentance: "A skill & habit mastery tool for ______". I think it would be neat to either advertise or begin with 2 subjects like this: "A rapid skill aquisition tool for weightliters and web developers" or for "barefoot runners and banjo players". I think rapid skill aquisition tool without any spoonfeeding or hard framework is really at the heart of Diarist. We can really feed off of anti-self help, that is spoonfeed-y, non-universal, rigid and cheesy material, in favor of "increased learning, your way" in a kind of guarenteed results vibe. Guarenteed results if you do your subject & write every day, or according to the schedule that you post (eminating keystone habit). This would be the only rigid part to the system. Helping with the RSA process via education & a framework involving habit, RSA, willpower, ect (all of the latest research) and their chosen subject. The latter will mainly lie in encourangement, connection with the community & suggestions from Diarist. I wonder: RAS pointed at amateurs with motivation, without telling them that they are amateurs. We dont want to target people who already have these skills. Remember, when they come to Diarist, they need to supply the motivation. The resevour of "i want to change", not laziness. ____ 6/20 Friday - Preliminary Research, App Flow Consolidating Ideas from TextEdit Notes As well as this primarily being a RAS tool, the what differentiates it from other systems is its dependance on the keystone habit: diary writing. For the community at large, the individual journies (diarys) bring a sense of unity, through the personal writing, to particularly difficult projects. As this pertains to guides and instructions on the internt: typically one must undergo struggle and then upon realization of their initial question or goal, they must synthesize a guide out of completion, often losing the personal journey & minute details that come during the journey to the answer. It is not the answer but the journey that counts, the journey is what makes the end unique. A user might first approach Diarist like this: I want to delve into the subject or learn this skill, but it has a large learning curve & I don’t know where to begin (what resources to look at, who to ask, what tools to use…) Again Diarist seems to be a great idea for multifaceted projects (those that seem overpowering and insurmountable) where multiple subjects/trade secrets/ect are involved, and not so great for surface level, specific questions (i.e. how do I release an album, how do I produce electronic music). On app flow: Posts include thoughts/setbacks/progress in the form of prose, video or pictures. This is day based, timeline based. Through this method of posting “small wins”, the emphasis is on a personal chronicle of struggle and success. The posting interface and service as a whole ties them together & spurs additional progress. “What I used, how I used it, what was the end product of me using it (ie. what did i learn, how did I feel about using it, how did this progress me towards my greater goal)” essentially self reflection intertwined with expository writing. Also, to spur progress Diarist could have awards: "Forger Award - first to complete a diary about this" Emails could look like: Here is what other people have said about this: - on diarist
- on specific internet resources
- on google
- in non-internet resources

these resources lead somewhere. After diary begins, video masterclass on progress ___ 6/21 & 6/22 Saturday, Sunday - Tidying Up & Expanding Posts (Streamlining & Wrap Up Idea Synthesis) Leaving posts raw. Is this important? Probably. For the future: MEAN Stack & Database Learning: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20605824/mean-stack-course-tutorial-node-js http://teamtreehouse.com/library/database-foundations

Small wins must fall between the chapters as they act as big wins. Weight Loss is the question we want you to ask, and the chapters are the many steps to get there. He mentions stress reduction, diet and excerise to name a few.

Baby steps with grace & meaning limit the amount of backsliding that may happen. You come to Diarist with the motivation, and we help you overcome the gap in ability. Not specifically, but by setting up a structure that allows you to do it yourself and will limit chance for failure, burnout & all other associated pitfalls. The structure most importantly supports and increases motivation. Although, rewards may be backsliding. 6 days and a cheat day.

This is what a cue is comprised of, and Fogg hits this right on the head: adiquite motivation, ability & a trigger. More of the specifics of his model can be found at: http://www.behaviormodel.org/index.html

In the case of "tiny habits" as Fogg presents them, he says much like Duhigg: using existing cues and replacing the routine works. Fogg suggests replacing the already small routine with a yet smaller one, increasing the likeliness that we will do it according to his motivation vs. skill chart.

Back to Duhigg: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=voX0gUn_JOI

He shines a light on the extrinsic means for the internal reward. At first, he says, cues and rewards must be external enough to trick the brain. Eventually they may fade into internal feelings in liu of the external reward which once provided those feelings.

He also goes into depth about the mechanics of habits of the individual and how groups support them emotionally. He says that intellectually we may be able to tell that we can change, but groups are important in moments of weakness.

AT 22:00 he talks about food journaling and how the process and repitition of documenting a process can lead you to avoidence of mistakes and progress. They learn their own patterns. Avoiding stupidity rather than being brilliant - Charlie Munger. He points out that willpower is easily taxed. Willpower is not used when actions are habitualized.

6/17 Tuesday - Preliminary Research
Motivation & Habits Specifics

http://blog.greatcodeclub.com/learn-new-things/
A great blog & resource to help developers take on side projects. A few great quotes here:

"However, my goal was never to learn how programming languages work. My goal was to create one, so I had to learn. I think this is very important. Learning for the sake of learning never worked for me, but learning because I wanted to do something with that knowledge did."

This post comes close to the proposed Diarist way of small wins journaling. The rules at the end are indespensable too. Yesterday, I remember an important thing that I forgot to write down. A habit for around a month usually cements it.

Two rules what have helped me are: ones from Leo Babatua "Make it a rule never to skip two days in a row." and one from freshman English 101, "always allows yourself to spew a 'shitty first draft'", editing on-the-go restricts the flow of ideas. These really have to do with both the app itself (what it gives to the user) and the flow (the meta, what the app is trying to achieve)

Babauta's list on his blog Zen Habits is a great summary of all the things I have discussed or in some capacity learned so far. http://zenhabits.net/top-20-motivation-hacks-4/
I felt good knowing that I could still learn from each of the points without seeing them as something completely new. It seems that what is coming soon is application of these points about habits and its processes into an app flow. Then, before learning MEAN & web app architechture I need to validate my idea with actual users.

A great place to look for further info would be Tim Ferriss & his books. As inspired by his "Day In the Life Of..." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pV2hLYqRnvY.

6/18 Wednesday - Preliminary Research
Clean-Up, Learning Curves & RAS

Did a little resource hunting today and transferring of ideas from numerous text edit files to this blog.

Kaufmen debunks the 10,000 hour rule. Found this to be encouraging. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5MgBikgcWnY
At 8:00 he talks about learning curves. Gives a great graph. Reinforces what I have learned so far, which is great because I know that I am on the right track.

He says it takes 20 hours to break the curve, via rapid skill aquisition . More definitley needs to be looked at on this topic. Tim Ferriss would be great. MAGICAL words after 10:00.

6/19 Thursday - Preliminary Research

Began Start Small, Stay Small by Walling. He avoids the venture-capital buisness-y startup lingo and communicates from a developers POV which is good. He stresses niche market, which I have read time and time again. I will need to target Diarist at a specific group. This can happen with the subjects. If we start the community with say, health and fitness/barefoot runners (super specific) and electronic music producers? Were going out "two or three descriptors" black barefoot runners, dubstep edm producers, ect...

After reading, I should probably fill in this sentance: "A skill & habit mastery tool for ______". I think it would be neat to either advertise or begin with 2 subjects like this: "A rapid skill aquisition tool for weightliters and web developers" or for "barefoot runners and banjo players". I think rapid skill aquisition tool without any spoonfeeding or hard framework is really at the heart of Diarist.

We can really feed off of anti-self help, that is spoonfeed-y, non-universal, rigid and cheesy material, in favor of "increased learning, your way" in a kind of guarenteed results vibe. Guarenteed results if you do your subject & write every day, or according to the schedule that you post (eminating keystone habit). This would be the only rigid part to the system. Helping with the RSA process via education & a framework involving habit, RSA, willpower, ect (all of the latest research) and their chosen subject. The latter will mainly lie in encourangement, connection with the community & suggestions from Diarist.

I wonder: RAS pointed at amateurs with motivation, without telling them that they are amateurs. We dont want to target people who already have these skills. Remember, when they come to Diarist, they need to supply the motivation. The resevour of "i want to change", not laziness.

6/20 Friday - Preliminary Research, App Flow
Consolidating Ideas from TextEdit Notes

As well as this primarily being a RAS tool, the what differentiates it from other systems is its dependance on the keystone habit: diary writing. For the community at large, the individual journies (diarys) bring a sense of unity, through the personal writing, to particularly difficult projects. As this pertains to guides and instructions on the internt: typically one must undergo struggle and then upon realization of their initial question or goal, they must synthesize a guide out of completion, often losing the personal journey & minute details that come during the journey to the answer. It is not the answer but the journey that counts, the journey is what makes the end unique.

A user might first approach Diarist like this: I want to delve into the subject or learn this skill,
but it has a large learning curve & I don’t know where to begin (what resources to look at, who to ask, what tools to use…) Again Diarist seems to be a great idea for multifaceted projects (those that seem overpowering and insurmountable) where multiple subjects/trade secrets/ect are involved, and not so great for surface level, specific questions (i.e. how do I release an album, how do I produce electronic music).

On app flow: Posts include thoughts/setbacks/progress in the form of prose, video or pictures. This is day based, timeline based. Through this method of posting “small wins”, the emphasis is on a personal chronicle of struggle and success. The posting interface and service as a whole ties them together & spurs additional progress. “What I used, how I used it, what was the end product of me using it (ie. what did i learn, how did I feel about using it, how did this progress me towards my greater goal)” essentially self reflection intertwined with expository writing.

Also, to spur progress Diarist could have awards: "Forger Award - first to complete a diary about this" Emails could look like: Here is what other people have said about this:
- on diarist
- on specific internet resources
- on google
- in non-internet resources

these resources lead somewhere.
After diary begins, video masterclass on progress

6/21 & 6/22 Saturday, Sunday - Tidying Up & Expanding Posts (Streamlining & Wrap Up Idea Synthesis)

Leaving posts raw. Is this important? Probably.

For the future:
MEAN Stack & Database Learning:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20605824/mean-stack-course-tutorial-node-js

http://teamtreehouse.com/library/database-foundations

####Week of 6/16 to 6/22

Current Print Resources:
The Mind’s I - Hofstadter & Dennett
Zen Flesh, Zen Bones - Reps & Senzaki
Logic: A Very Short Introduction - Priest
An Introduction to Non-Classical Logic - Priest
The Power of Habit - Charles Duhigg

[TED - Mattieu Ricard on Habits of Happiness](https://www.ted.com/talks/matthieu_ricard_on_the_habits_of_happiness#t-728104)

Negative states do not inherintly exist inside the mind. - 6/16
___
[Edge - Pinker on Writing in the 21st Century](http://edge.org/conversation/writing-in-the-21st-century)
___
[Edge - Knobe on Experimental Philosophy](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HO4_AeLtAPg)
___
[TED - Searle on Conciousness as a Shared Condition](https://www.ted.com/talks/john_searle_our_shared_condition_consciousness#t-306783) 
___
[TED - Sheldrake on The Science Delusion](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1TerTgDEgUE)

Debasing the ultimate certainty and religiosity of modern science culture. Sheldrake draws the lines in the sand between science as a method of inquiry and science as a revival of philosophical materialism.  - 6/17

___
[FS Mental Models](http://www.farnamstreetblog.com/mental-models/)

Drawing heavily from Charlie Munger's mental models, Parrish forms his own list of framworks for thinking. His article on Munger's "Inversion" brought me here, and I immediately thought that it would be a novel idea to translate these into logical symbols. For instance:

####“Inversion”
I will create a good web app = A . B
**I will not create a not good web app = ~(A . ~B)

6/18
___

[Matte on The Beauty of Mathematics](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SEiSloE1r-A)

Lo and behold, Matte begins the talk with an excerpt from Plato's Meno. Plato's theory of knowledge & epistemology in general will be important to come back to.

6/19
___

####Proposed Resources:
Godel, Escher, Bach - Hofstadter
Minds, Brains and Science - Searle
How the Mind Works - Pinker
The Society of Mind - Minsky

Hilary Putnam
David Chalmers
An Analysis of Paul Laffoley's Art & Writing
on the Mind,  [Cosmic Creativity - Alex Grey](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0_YJToyOp_4)

http://cs.lmu.edu/~ray/notes/logic/
Logic 2nd ed. - Stan Barronett (Some type of logic textbook w/ workable problems)
http://cs.lmu.edu/~ray/classes/nt/
http://www.fecundity.com/logic/download.html
http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dialetheism/
http://philosophy.stackexchange.com/
http://philosophy.stackexchange.com/questions/6482/what-are-the-dialetheist-semantics-for-logical-negation
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0300188374/farnamstreet-20

Proposed Resources:
"Poor Charlie's Almanack" - Charles Munger (I am very interested in the logical basis for his famous "mental models")
"Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking" - Daniel Dennett
"Computability & Logic" - Boolos & Burgess

___

[Dennett on Thinking Tools - iqsquared](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EJsD-3jtXz0)

Need to read "Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking" by Dennett - 6/25

___

[The Loginataka](http://catb.org/~esr/faqs/loginataka.html)

Pretty funny and informative look at Unix Wizardry written in the vein of old eastern religious texts. - 6/27

[Unix Koans](http://www.catb.org/~esr//writings/unix-koans/ten-thousand.html)

[Conciousness as a Mathmatical Product](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GzCvlFRISIM)

[Dark Patterns](http://darkpatterns.org/)

Machine Learning
Data Mining/Science
Meta Learning (Logic, Heauristics and Intuition Pumps motivate meta learning)
Haskell
Rust
Bash
"Artificial Creativity"

[Humans Need Not Apply](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Pq-S557XQU)

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLT6gX_wy0SNr7FChxKoPzo5ootwaA_HZX
