posts.title: Skillgenie 2
posts.markdown:
#####Chapters:
Preliminary Research
App Flow/Wireframing (Framework)
Milestone: Initial Marketing Site
Market Validation
Web App (Backend) Basics w/ Parse & Backbone.js
Development Phase 1

___

Monday 6/23 - Preliminary Research
RSA + LAL

As far as I know and with a quick Google search, there are no existing RSA apps. I think this will be one of the keys to successful marketing & learning curve conquest, however, not the focus of the entire app. There is a whole no-man's-land after the curve that we need to fulfill, but I think that RSA principles combined with the keystone habit of the daily diary metric will fill in a lot of the details of the gap.

One of the essential parts of getting people to go along with this system is providing them with education on the process itself and the ways in which they should make progress. For instance, learning about learning (LAL). How do I know which skills I need to learn to get to my end goal. Essentially, this will be RSA over and over again between sub-goals to get to the end.

___

Tuesday 6/24 - Market Validation
Niches & Overall Goal

My journey today began with an email from Fizzle, "Why Finding Your Niche is Just Plain Bad Advice." It turns out that the niche idea itself needed to be redefined to target a psychographic within a demographic. The first is what you shoot for, the second is the general area in which you market. This way, you never lose the market say if the 13 year old girl you once marketed towards becomes a 30 year old mom. Their ambitions may not always be the same, but old attachments/dreams/passions die hard.

The author then addresses a very minimalist view towards amassing an audience or getting people to pay attention. I the applicable steps in summary are these:
1. Make a good product/content around a certain niche (redefined to "worldview")
2. Connect with people in the niche, "leverage their platforms."


The steps in market validation, or making sure that the market exists, is large enough and that your product will be well received are:
1. If you want to be Betty Crocker, first set up a lemonade stand. Create a rough draft or even a picture of the rough draft, with all of the initial marketing built in. An example of this would be a site that allows a hype-y sneak peak, gives a release date and then collects a contact email. Think kickstarter. It would then provide constant updates, maybe a link to this blog?
2. Direct people to the site.

#####Dialing things back a bit
The idea for Diarist is not fully formed, and it is overwhelming me. Here is what I do know:
>There will be a web application that I write in some capacity.

>There is a system or one or two (habit loops, RSA) that can be combined, exploited, and stripped into a framework to be molded into said app.

>This system of daily, Diarist based writing as a keystone habit is working for me. The weekends as a concession, cheat-day also works marvelously.

>Most importantly and most certainly, the market that I need to focus on is the "lifehacker", the rapid skill acquisition & habit changing self-experimenters, those who are willing to work & be aided (shortcutters), not the lazy. The 4HWW & I Will Teach You To Be Rich crowd. Even those that would read the Power of Habit! Self-improvement, not self-help. 

The habit loop of my diary writing:
1. Trigger: A lull in work & a "remember to do" thought.
2. Routine: Research & writing (simultaneously)
3. Reward: Feeling of accomplishment, guiltless play.
4. Craving: For Meaning.

___

Wednesday 6/25 - Preliminary Research
Refocusing & RSA Frameworks

Diarist probably needs to be renamed, but for now, we refocus to an RSA app. I'd say that the next few steps are to identify common frameworks for this and it's outlying dependancies, deconstruct them and apply them.

At its core, Diarist will boil down (framework) and put into app form the leading "systems" on skill acquisition. When finished with the acquisition, the user will be able to have that acquisition (put into guide form by the app) associated with him and broadcast into the community for glory. He will be able to track how many people have used his methods, either the entire guide or specific parts, say, his 1 of his 3 Minimum Effective Doses. The community will be connected in this way, and will drive the app through the competitive, motivated and demanding nature of its users. The idea is no longer a long term project tracker, but a fast pace race against the clock, or yourself in this case.

I am still into the idea of daily tracking, but no doubt any RSA system will prescribe such a daily check in. It largely depends on the framework that we come up with. Daily tracking could be any type of media or format of writing (bullets, paragraphs, ect..)

As for development, the MEAN stack will be too complicated. A conversation with my boss and friend lead me to the KISS acronym. Keep it simple stupid! Too many difficult learning curves at once will destroy my ambition to complete this project.

MEAN is a stack, and I don't really need a stack of separate languages when I am trying to learn web app fundamentals and construct a basic web app. Upon a recommendation from a friend. I will now use Parse + Backbone.js (Backend), JQuery (Middleware) and HTML/CSS/Bootstrap (Frontend). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ATktgoXu9s

For the initial app flow, I will keep in mind the absolute minimum amount of functionality needed to implement the very basic idea of the app.

Back to the building metaphor if the building is the overall accomplishment, the app definitely needs to provide the scaffolding, the user provides the workers and I am undecided on whether we are to provide the food and praise sustain the workers (motivation by way of habit loops, "internet points"/incentivization, ect..).

As for different RSA systems I know of these so far:
Tim Ferriss - DSSS https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WzyvvkiUIKY
Josh Kaufman - First 20 Hours
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lB6K60mkmho
http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/how-to-acquire-any-new-skill-in-20-hours-or-less/
Malcolm Gladwell - 10,000 Hours in "Outliers"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7k4kv2xW7JM
Random Hodge-podge of Blogs
http://lifehacker.com/the-science-behind-how-we-learn-new-skills-908488422




Expanding on marketing:
Do more, work less. Essentially we need to remove everything about the acquisition process so that all there is left to do is the leg work. Like putting blinders on a horse, it does not tell the horse where to go, but narrows the path so that the chances of him getting there greatly increase. The end goal will not be to become expert, but to become adequate. So that they "Know what they're doing."

___

6/26 Thursday - App Flow
Ferriss Framework: DiSSS & CaFE

These frameworks proposed by Ferriss, Kaufmen and to a certain extent Gladwell, all have nessecarily the same steps and are basically mental "frameworks". It would probably benefit me to read more about Munger's mental models, as they seem to be useful and similar in wading through these RSA systems. My job will be to give representation in an app for what happens explicitly in the framework and appropriately guide what happens implicitly for the user, making it all interactive so all that is left is the leg work.

Page 38 in the 4HChef is the perfect framework. Ferriss sets up DiSSS as the explicit framework and CaFE (and earlier remarks about emotional blockage, fear, ect..) as the implicit mental happenings that specifically aid the legwork. 

1. User enters all of the "minimum learnable units"
2. User selects the most important of the units
3. User orders these important units
4. User sets up stakes

Say that 1,2,3 are the beginning, the leg work (CaFE) happens in the middle, and 4 is realized at the end. The user basically defines the beginning and end of the project first and then fills in the gaps.

Users also need to set up CaFE, especially frequency. This will allow the app to remind them and send them resources. 

I believe that the learnable units and stakes will play the largest role in the community aspect of this, which is really becoming increasingly important. The overall topic and learnable units are community links because they are suggested and searchable, maybe one gets awarded for using less or more unique units? The stakes motivate the competitive and urgency aspects of the user and community. The user is simple enough, when they finish a unit, they can record their progress and be rewarded with validation to the community, metrics about how pieces of their progression is being used by the community, achievements, points, ect... How stakes as they relate to a unit or a whole skill are going to integrate with the community, I don't know. We don't want users to be pitted against each other like: "You and Bill will run the La Jolla Half Marathon in 2 months", this is to blatant of an accountabilibuddy. At some level there needs to be approval or disapproval from the community about what the members of it are doing in their personal skill trees.

Instead of blogging in between the units, the user is only prompted to share information or validate that he has completed that unit, when he has completed the unit. No mandatory intermediate posts.

There is a skeleton framework, listed above that will be the core of the app. But, RSA is as much dependent on the framework as well as the mindset, there is a highly demanding mental part of doing the least amount for the most gain. Whether this instruction is integrated with the core or proposed as a "tutorial", since we are already gamifying with the community and the stakes, i do not know.

By the way, skills or entire subjects need to be "two nouns out". This means that Learning Japanese is not good. Learning All of the Japanese Kanji is good. Playing guitar is not good. Playing Blues guitar is good. Remember that this is not a prolonged-research project, it is a semi-specific, fast paced, competitive, amateur (in the vein of Kaufmen), rapid skill acquisition. This is NOT a project guide or mastery of a skill. This app would be good, say in this situation for learning my "Web App with Parse & Backbone.js" section. Even build a web app would be fine, not create a top 100 app from scratch. Skill, not project based. Most of these rules need to be implicit in the design of the program, there should not be "learn all this stuff" to use my app to "learn more stuff."

####Groundwork & Deconstruction
> To the man with only a hammer, every problem looks like a nail. - Abraham Maslow

>When you first start to study a field, it seems like you have to memorize a zillion things. You don’t. What you need is to identify the core principles – generally three to twelve of them – that govern the field. The million things you thought you had to memorize are simply various combinations of the core principles - John T. Reed

This will the the process of breaking apart the skill into the minimum learnable units. Finding these is the difficult part, which will be either taught or integrated into the app. I vote for integration, but I lack ideas about how to do this currently. Anyway, there are specific mental models or "deconstructors" or tools by which to deconstruct that you can run the skill through and out will pop the parts. There are obviously many more, but I see 5 right now. It is necessary to stress that some of these may work for some skills and not for others. This section could greatly expand upon integration Munger's models and [Farnam Street's models](http://www.farnamstreetblog.com/mental-models/).

Before addressing the models, information needs to be provided on finding materials on the skill from which to deconstruct the units. The user needs to have information on the groundwork for their subject. Maybe we instruct the user to find some authoritative or classic resources on the skill? Suggestions should be pulled for them. Again, little tricks can be provided for example:
- Read overview materials, look for top rated books on the skill on Google or Amazon.
- Look at the author's bibliography or keep an eye out for any mention of leading or classic resources
- Youtube
- Look for leading content.

Reduction: The common parts between many things. This works well for numerous instances of memorization. Japanese characters, dance routines, blues songs. For example in every blues song there is usually certain common chords, certain common progressions and certain common licks. Learning 3 blues boxes or scales could yield infinite popular blues licks.

Inversion:

Translation:

Negation: What a bad person does.

Interview or "Expert-Watching": 

These units are "Action-centric" (Principles) not "Thing-centric" (Specifics). For instance: DO: time yourself while tying knots, aim to get faster with each time. NOT: learn to tie a hookydoodle knot.

"Thing-centric" units are valid, but should be reserved and separated from the minimum learnable units, as simply learning a square knot is extremely beneficial to the knot tying discipline, as is buying rope. How these will be integrated with the system, just as a list of resources and applications, has yet to be determined.

Presumably these units have already been internalized or read in the pre-deconstruction stage of resource finding. 

"Thing-centric" units limit the user from personalizing the process and separate them from the process itself, which will probably lead to failure. However if there is some must read book on knot tying, it is probably important.

What and why professional knot tiers are doing what they are doing is more concerning than the specifics of how they are doing it.


####Selection
Is what covers the most ground. If you were looking at a linear representation with the skill on a line with amateur and expert on either end, what did they do that allowed them to cover the most ground on the line? What are the biggest small wins?


####More Proposed Resources relating to RSA:

- The Cambridge Handbook of Expertise and Expert Performance 

- The Cambridge Handbook of Thinking and Reasoning

- Seeking Wisdom: From Darwin to Munger, 3rd Edition

- [The Makings of An Expert - Anders Ericsson](http://www.uvm.edu/~pdodds/files/papers/others/everything/ericsson2007a.pdf)

- The Little Book of Talent: 52 Tips for Improving Your Skills

- The Road To Excellence: The Acquisition of Expert Performance in the Arts and Sciences, Sports, and Games


By reading these books, we will identify what methods are similar and overlap in getting to  an amateur status and a master status. Figuring out what is the MED for amateurism, that mimics those methods that masters use? 

___

5/27 Friday - Preliminary Research

> Learning to program is like learning to write good natural language. The best way to do it is to read some stuff written by masters of the form, write some things yourself, read a lot more, write a little more, read a lot more, write some more ... and repeat until your writing begins to develop the kind of strength and economy you see in your models. - Eric Steven Raymond in [How to Become a Hacker](http://www.catb.org/esr/faqs/hacker-howto.html)

An essay for programmers similar to Gladwell's 10,000 hours, http://norvig.com/21-days.html

A great summary of the beginning of Kaufmen's book by Ramit Sethi, http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/how-to-acquire-any-new-skill-in-20-hours-or-less/

For web app flow, http://bitovi.com/blog/2014/06/web-app-theory.html

More on the skill declaring, my two nouns out thing is covered in Kaufman's "Target Performance Level". The TAL is set after the skill, this is often what is two or three nouns out more importantly "what is achievable for the amateur you!". The skill declaration is general: "Doing yoga." TAL is digging deeply and realistically, "I want to set up a personal, at-home yoga practice."

The units are subskills, achieving these subskills is motivated by frequency ie habit loops.

Important terms to define will be learnable units (whether they are subskills or what! CLEARLY), skill declaration and TAL.
posts.html:
Chapters:

Preliminary Research
App Flow/Wireframing (Framework)
Milestone: Initial Marketing Site
Market Validation
Web App (Backend) Basics w/ Parse & Backbone.js
Development Phase 1

Monday 6/23 - Preliminary Research
RSA + LAL

As far as I know and with a quick Google search, there are no existing RSA apps. I think this will be one of the keys to successful marketing & learning curve conquest, however, not the focus of the entire app. There is a whole no-man's-land after the curve that we need to fulfill, but I think that RSA principles combined with the keystone habit of the daily diary metric will fill in a lot of the details of the gap.

One of the essential parts of getting people to go along with this system is providing them with education on the process itself and the ways in which they should make progress. For instance, learning about learning (LAL). How do I know which skills I need to learn to get to my end goal. Essentially, this will be RSA over and over again between sub-goals to get to the end.

Tuesday 6/24 - Market Validation
Niches & Overall Goal

My journey today began with an email from Fizzle, "Why Finding Your Niche is Just Plain Bad Advice." It turns out that the niche idea itself needed to be redefined to target a psychographic within a demographic. The first is what you shoot for, the second is the general area in which you market. This way, you never lose the market say if the 13 year old girl you once marketed towards becomes a 30 year old mom. Their ambitions may not always be the same, but old attachments/dreams/passions die hard.

The author then addresses a very minimalist view towards amassing an audience or getting people to pay attention. I the applicable steps in summary are these:
1. Make a good product/content around a certain niche (redefined to "worldview")
2. Connect with people in the niche, "leverage their platforms."

The steps in market validation, or making sure that the market exists, is large enough and that your product will be well received are:
1. If you want to be Betty Crocker, first set up a lemonade stand. Create a rough draft or even a picture of the rough draft, with all of the initial marketing built in. An example of this would be a site that allows a hype-y sneak peak, gives a release date and then collects a contact email. Think kickstarter. It would then provide constant updates, maybe a link to this blog?
2. Direct people to the site.

Dialing things back a bit

The idea for Diarist is not fully formed, and it is overwhelming me. Here is what I do know:

There will be a web application that I write in some capacity.

There is a system or one or two (habit loops, RSA) that can be combined, exploited, and stripped into a framework to be molded into said app.

This system of daily, Diarist based writing as a keystone habit is working for me. The weekends as a concession, cheat-day also works marvelously.

Most importantly and most certainly, the market that I need to focus on is the "lifehacker", the rapid skill acquisition & habit changing self-experimenters, those who are willing to work & be aided (shortcutters), not the lazy. The 4HWW & I Will Teach You To Be Rich crowd. Even those that would read the Power of Habit! Self-improvement, not self-help.

The habit loop of my diary writing:
1. Trigger: A lull in work & a "remember to do" thought.
2. Routine: Research & writing (simultaneously)
3. Reward: Feeling of accomplishment, guiltless play.
4. Craving: For Meaning.

Wednesday 6/25 - Preliminary Research
Refocusing & RSA Frameworks

Diarist probably needs to be renamed, but for now, we refocus to an RSA app. I'd say that the next few steps are to identify common frameworks for this and it's outlying dependancies, deconstruct them and apply them.

At its core, Diarist will boil down (framework) and put into app form the leading "systems" on skill acquisition. When finished with the acquisition, the user will be able to have that acquisition (put into guide form by the app) associated with him and broadcast into the community for glory. He will be able to track how many people have used his methods, either the entire guide or specific parts, say, his 1 of his 3 Minimum Effective Doses. The community will be connected in this way, and will drive the app through the competitive, motivated and demanding nature of its users. The idea is no longer a long term project tracker, but a fast pace race against the clock, or yourself in this case.

I am still into the idea of daily tracking, but no doubt any RSA system will prescribe such a daily check in. It largely depends on the framework that we come up with. Daily tracking could be any type of media or format of writing (bullets, paragraphs, ect..)

As for development, the MEAN stack will be too complicated. A conversation with my boss and friend lead me to the KISS acronym. Keep it simple stupid! Too many difficult learning curves at once will destroy my ambition to complete this project.

MEAN is a stack, and I don't really need a stack of separate languages when I am trying to learn web app fundamentals and construct a basic web app. Upon a recommendation from a friend. I will now use Parse + Backbone.js (Backend), JQuery (Middleware) and HTML/CSS/Bootstrap (Frontend). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ATktgoXu9s

For the initial app flow, I will keep in mind the absolute minimum amount of functionality needed to implement the very basic idea of the app.

Back to the building metaphor if the building is the overall accomplishment, the app definitely needs to provide the scaffolding, the user provides the workers and I am undecided on whether we are to provide the food and praise sustain the workers (motivation by way of habit loops, "internet points"/incentivization, ect..).

As for different RSA systems I know of these so far:
Tim Ferriss - DSSS https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WzyvvkiUIKY
Josh Kaufman - First 20 Hours
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lB6K60mkmho
http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/how-to-acquire-any-new-skill-in-20-hours-or-less/
Malcolm Gladwell - 10,000 Hours in "Outliers"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7k4kv2xW7JM
Random Hodge-podge of Blogs
http://lifehacker.com/the-science-behind-how-we-learn-new-skills-908488422

Expanding on marketing:
Do more, work less. Essentially we need to remove everything about the acquisition process so that all there is left to do is the leg work. Like putting blinders on a horse, it does not tell the horse where to go, but narrows the path so that the chances of him getting there greatly increase. The end goal will not be to become expert, but to become adequate. So that they "Know what they're doing."

6/26 Thursday - App Flow
Ferriss Framework: DiSSS & CaFE

These frameworks proposed by Ferriss, Kaufmen and to a certain extent Gladwell, all have nessecarily the same steps and are basically mental "frameworks". It would probably benefit me to read more about Munger's mental models, as they seem to be useful and similar in wading through these RSA systems. My job will be to give representation in an app for what happens explicitly in the framework and appropriately guide what happens implicitly for the user, making it all interactive so all that is left is the leg work.

Page 38 in the 4HChef is the perfect framework. Ferriss sets up DiSSS as the explicit framework and CaFE (and earlier remarks about emotional blockage, fear, ect..) as the implicit mental happenings that specifically aid the legwork.

  1. User enters all of the "minimum learnable units"
  2. User selects the most important of the units
  3. User orders these important units
  4. User sets up stakes

Say that 1,2,3 are the beginning, the leg work (CaFE) happens in the middle, and 4 is realized at the end. The user basically defines the beginning and end of the project first and then fills in the gaps.

Users also need to set up CaFE, especially frequency. This will allow the app to remind them and send them resources.

I believe that the learnable units and stakes will play the largest role in the community aspect of this, which is really becoming increasingly important. The overall topic and learnable units are community links because they are suggested and searchable, maybe one gets awarded for using less or more unique units? The stakes motivate the competitive and urgency aspects of the user and community. The user is simple enough, when they finish a unit, they can record their progress and be rewarded with validation to the community, metrics about how pieces of their progression is being used by the community, achievements, points, ect... How stakes as they relate to a unit or a whole skill are going to integrate with the community, I don't know. We don't want users to be pitted against each other like: "You and Bill will run the La Jolla Half Marathon in 2 months", this is to blatant of an accountabilibuddy. At some level there needs to be approval or disapproval from the community about what the members of it are doing in their personal skill trees.

Instead of blogging in between the units, the user is only prompted to share information or validate that he has completed that unit, when he has completed the unit. No mandatory intermediate posts.

There is a skeleton framework, listed above that will be the core of the app. But, RSA is as much dependent on the framework as well as the mindset, there is a highly demanding mental part of doing the least amount for the most gain. Whether this instruction is integrated with the core or proposed as a "tutorial", since we are already gamifying with the community and the stakes, i do not know.

By the way, skills or entire subjects need to be "two nouns out". This means that Learning Japanese is not good. Learning All of the Japanese Kanji is good. Playing guitar is not good. Playing Blues guitar is good. Remember that this is not a prolonged-research project, it is a semi-specific, fast paced, competitive, amateur (in the vein of Kaufmen), rapid skill acquisition. This is NOT a project guide or mastery of a skill. This app would be good, say in this situation for learning my "Web App with Parse & Backbone.js" section. Even build a web app would be fine, not create a top 100 app from scratch. Skill, not project based. Most of these rules need to be implicit in the design of the program, there should not be "learn all this stuff" to use my app to "learn more stuff."

Groundwork & Deconstruction

To the man with only a hammer, every problem looks like a nail. - Abraham Maslow

When you first start to study a field, it seems like you have to memorize a zillion things. You don’t. What you need is to identify the core principles – generally three to twelve of them – that govern the field. The million things you thought you had to memorize are simply various combinations of the core principles - John T. Reed

This will the the process of breaking apart the skill into the minimum learnable units. Finding these is the difficult part, which will be either taught or integrated into the app. I vote for integration, but I lack ideas about how to do this currently. Anyway, there are specific mental models or "deconstructors" or tools by which to deconstruct that you can run the skill through and out will pop the parts. There are obviously many more, but I see 5 right now. It is necessary to stress that some of these may work for some skills and not for others. This section could greatly expand upon integration Munger's models and Farnam Street's models.

Before addressing the models, information needs to be provided on finding materials on the skill from which to deconstruct the units. The user needs to have information on the groundwork for their subject. Maybe we instruct the user to find some authoritative or classic resources on the skill? Suggestions should be pulled for them. Again, little tricks can be provided for example:
- Read overview materials, look for top rated books on the skill on Google or Amazon. - Look at the author's bibliography or keep an eye out for any mention of leading or classic resources - Youtube - Look for leading content.

Reduction: The common parts between many things. This works well for numerous instances of memorization. Japanese characters, dance routines, blues songs. For example in every blues song there is usually certain common chords, certain common progressions and certain common licks. Learning 3 blues boxes or scales could yield infinite popular blues licks.

Inversion:

Translation:

Negation: What a bad person does.

Interview or "Expert-Watching":

These units are "Action-centric" (Principles) not "Thing-centric" (Specifics). For instance: DO: time yourself while tying knots, aim to get faster with each time. NOT: learn to tie a hookydoodle knot.

"Thing-centric" units are valid, but should be reserved and separated from the minimum learnable units, as simply learning a square knot is extremely beneficial to the knot tying discipline, as is buying rope. How these will be integrated with the system, just as a list of resources and applications, has yet to be determined.

Presumably these units have already been internalized or read in the pre-deconstruction stage of resource finding.

"Thing-centric" units limit the user from personalizing the process and separate them from the process itself, which will probably lead to failure. However if there is some must read book on knot tying, it is probably important.

What and why professional knot tiers are doing what they are doing is more concerning than the specifics of how they are doing it.

Selection

Is what covers the most ground. If you were looking at a linear representation with the skill on a line with amateur and expert on either end, what did they do that allowed them to cover the most ground on the line? What are the biggest small wins?

More Proposed Resources relating to RSA:

  • The Cambridge Handbook of Expertise and Expert Performance

  • The Cambridge Handbook of Thinking and Reasoning

  • Seeking Wisdom: From Darwin to Munger, 3rd Edition

  • The Makings of An Expert - Anders Ericsson

  • The Little Book of Talent: 52 Tips for Improving Your Skills

  • The Road To Excellence: The Acquisition of Expert Performance in the Arts and Sciences, Sports, and Games

By reading these books, we will identify what methods are similar and overlap in getting to an amateur status and a master status. Figuring out what is the MED for amateurism, that mimics those methods that masters use?

5/27 Friday - Preliminary Research

Learning to program is like learning to write good natural language. The best way to do it is to read some stuff written by masters of the form, write some things yourself, read a lot more, write a little more, read a lot more, write some more ... and repeat until your writing begins to develop the kind of strength and economy you see in your models. - Eric Steven Raymond in How to Become a Hacker

An essay for programmers similar to Gladwell's 10,000 hours, http://norvig.com/21-days.html

A great summary of the beginning of Kaufmen's book by Ramit Sethi, http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/how-to-acquire-any-new-skill-in-20-hours-or-less/

For web app flow, http://bitovi.com/blog/2014/06/web-app-theory.html

More on the skill declaring, my two nouns out thing is covered in Kaufman's "Target Performance Level". The TAL is set after the skill, this is often what is two or three nouns out more importantly "what is achievable for the amateur you!". The skill declaration is general: "Doing yoga." TAL is digging deeply and realistically, "I want to set up a personal, at-home yoga practice."

The units are subskills, achieving these subskills is motivated by frequency ie habit loops.

Important terms to define will be learnable units (whether they are subskills or what! CLEARLY), skill declaration and TAL.

posts.title: Skillgenie 3
posts.markdown:
Monday - 6/30 

Research multiple systems, integrate

Wireframing will be a good tool to see if "appification" of a certain step is feasible. This kind of sits halfway between theory and practice, both of which need to be tested.

https://wireframe.cc/ or pages

So far, the systems stand at
I. UNDER RSA SPECIFICALLY:
+ Ferriss DiSSS & CaFE
+ Kaufman's 20 Hours
+ Random Blog Musings

II. UNDER COMPLETE MASTERY (a la "Gladwell"):
+ Academic Articles (most) on Skill Aquisition (spec. Anders Ericsson & Ruth Clark)

Excerpt From: Kaufman, Josh. “The First 20 Hours: How to Learn Anything . . . Fast!.” iBooks. https://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewBook?id=995A4B4B3A7BC1F5EAEA1246B6B14CCB

III. UNDER GENERAL LEARNING:

>Ranked for importance
___
Tuesday - 7/1

Important question of the day is: What resources did Ferriss and Kaufman use? This could lead me towards more academic, research based systems, which is what I need!
>Maybe I should take my own advice & look at their bibliographies...

Here is another batch of resources to look into: will help with the app design. "Instructional Design" specifically, Design For How People Learn (Voices That Matter) by Dirksen.

####Kaufman:
“VanLehn, Kurt. “Cognitive Skill Acquisition.” Annual Review of Psychology 47, no. 1 (1996): 513–539.”

“Newell, Allen, and Paul S. Rosenbloom. “Mechanisms of Skill Acquisition and the Law of Practice.” Cognitive Skills and Their Acquisition (1981): 1–55.”

"Feynman Technique"

Switching gears to marketing:
I think it is just about time that we gain market validation. To see if we need to go back to the drawing board. I propose simply making a product homepage "update you when we are ready", set a tentative alpha date, get there information (email), provide incentive to sign up, tell about features ect. 4HWW would be good for this, also http://blog.gumroad.com/post/75142076006/anatomy-of-an-effective-product-page. There are really two levels to this: marketing and design.

Hybrid app/RSA course?

### Curve
####Curve is a skill aquisition framework built to help normal people do extrodinary things. 

Our hope is that by harnessing the latest research by academics, authors, and bloggers alike, we will be able to build a strong community that will push the boundaries of learning. The framework is only half the battle, we need you.

Help us consider the "learning curve" a thing of the past. 

Made sales test site wireframe


___
Wednesday - 7/2
Domains & Measuring Demand

curvatu.re would be a pretty cool domain name. Or just some version of curveapp. 

The "Start Small, Stay Small" book & 4HWW both have similar and great ideas for measuring demand. My main strategy will be to build a small marketing site and see how many people I can get to "opt-in". I should clearly identify where "lifehacker" types hang out & blogs that they might read. Off the top of my head I would go for Tim Ferriss' blog, Zen Habits, Lifehacker, reddit, hackernews ect. Then I need to direct traffic to my site through ads, but more likely guest articles and championing by others to "measure demand". Previously, I can use adwords & other keyword tools. Definitly needs to have conversion trackers on the site.

####Current Research Reading:
The Oxford Handbook of Thinking and Reasoning

The Cambridge Handbook of Expertise and Expert Performance 

Building Expertise - Cognitive Methods for Training and Performance Improvement by Ruth Clark (ebrary)

The Creative Habit by Twyla Tharp


May use Meteor.js instead of Parse. Looks newer and transparently uses the MEAN stack, instead of the "behind closed doors" feel or Parse or Firebase. Eww firebase...

Meteor takes care of Express & Angular, thank god, leaving only their special implimentation of Mongo (MiniMongo) & Node.js. I need to learn about document (JSON) databases (NoSQL) before I begin. High hopes though.

Need to find effective web app mockups for the marketing mini site. The list of crowdfunding sites that this guy has are golden for finding short app marketing pitches & mockups. http://www.apptamin.com/blog/get-funding-mobile-app/

Also this:
http://www.apptamin.com/blog/create-your-apps-website-before-your-first-line-of-code/

...speaks for itself.
___
Thursday - 7/3
App Flow

Just transferring paper notes now...
Some slogans:
"Learn more, do less"
"A framwork for rapid skill aquisition"
"An api for life"

I was pretty fond of the last one, so It kind of spurred an idea. What if we split Curve into two parts a la an api and a program made with it. Obviously we cannot make it "cheesily" code based: deconstructSkill(); but I believe it would be intelligent to nod our head to successful APIs and the ways that they are put together. 

In my head, the framework is comprise of two things the interactive skill interface and the educative element (the docs). The two will play heavily off of eachother, especially from interface -> docs. I decided that we will let users take care of any subject specific material, we will really only provide resources on the "meta" of it all. In this way, users must be able to use MED's or Subskills that belong to other users. Another cool thing would be for any changes or material by users to be commited to the docs immediately (async w/ Meteor!). So that the docs contain both the "meta-learning" info and material/best practices organized by subject. Anything inputted by the user will be "highly modualar" and availible for use by the community.

As far as what goes into the docs, I imagine in the vein of APIs we have sections and forms of usage (predetermined "methods" - models, heuristics, best practices and/or just general info). For example under the "Deconstruction" section we could have various models and their usages to create MEDs, and under "Target Application Level" we just have a definition and examples. Examples will be key for all.

Some thoughts on Skill defining for the user, we should have a Subject, Skill, Target approach. That is: what general catagory the skill falls under, what the skill is (two nouns out), what the user's target application is. Ex: Programming, "I want to learn server-side code", "I want to make a multi-user prototype of the Curve web app with Meteor.js (MEAN)".

Some thoughts on the opt in. We will have Closed Alpha and Open Beta for the stages of user "population"/bug fixes and subject specific content creation. Users that opt in within the mini site period will be invited to closed alpha, a basic features and information prototype. It is very important that they are introduced as the "first" that matter very much, we need to build a strong community or power users. Open Beta will be an open beta, with all of the three goals in mind, but with user leniency (they are scouting for bugs and creating content) and new alpha-distinct features. 

This is important: http://zenhabits.net/top-20-motivation-hacks-19/

Zen Habits is another phenominal source along with the Minimalists for blog style RSA. They should be added as a close second to Ferriss and Kaufman

Another good resource to view marketing, apps, website setup: https://news.ycombinator.com/show
Almost better than HackerNews: http://www.producthunt.com/

Fantastic: http://blog.frontapp.com/hacker-news-techcrunch-and-product-hunt-which-is-most-effective-to-launch-your-product-2/

Awesome: http://goodui.org/

####Back to research:
From the Handbook of Expert...

Cruve docs will essentially be a "knowledge base" as defined in Expert Systems (91). It will encompass factual knowledge about meta-learning, but its focus will be heuristic knowledge or flipping heuristics into facts (like Munger with his models). This knowledge is, "experiental, more judgemental [intuition-al] knowledge of performance. Rarely discussed and largely individualistic." This is the cornerstone of Curve, to illicit heuristic knowledge from users about skills and help others to apply this knowledge. "It is knowledge of good practice, good judgement, and plausible reasoning within the domain. It is the knowledge that underlies the art of good guessing."

>"Experience is a prerequisite to human expertise... expertise gained through experience can be codified in the knowledge base as rules, heuristics, definitions, taxonomies, prototypes, statstics of prior associations [and] previously solved cases."

When I am ready to actually design the knowledge base, I need to come back to Part 3 (127) and basically read the book from there. 

####So far we have:
#####Skill Declaration 
(Subject, Skill, Target)
 >"A problem well stated is a problem half solved"
 
 Docs: Lovability of skill choice

#####Deconstruction 
(Distilling expertise - Finding other's "best practices", Defining subskills (What are the essential in between steps, subjects, ect, NOUN CENTRIC) these are a distillation of the actions (VERB CENTRIC - best practices) of the experts)

#####Selection
(Deals with thinning out deconstructive research, Grouping and 80/20ing subskills, Formation of *your* "best practices" on for each subskill (MEDs). (Actionable steps to achieve subskills, VERB CENTRIC))
> What is common among best performers, infrequently taught and accords with personal strenghts.

#####Sequencing 
(Deals with ordering "best practices", frequency, habits, feedback loops, practice periods, selecting tools)
 
Docs: willpower as a muscle, ZenHabits

#####Stakes
(Deals with commitment and end product)
 
####As for major resources we have at our disposal: Kaufman, Ferriss, Duhigg, Ericsson.


A note on the "rapidity" of this system, it is not defined by hours or time. The only goal we have is to meet the sweet spot between time and aquisition based on your target. The curve is different for all people and all subjects. We do not encourage you to set the bar low or shoot for the stars, rather set a realistic goal and go for it.

####An example of MEDs, subskills, and targets

Subject: Fitness

Skill: Weight Management

Target: I want to get back down to my pre pregancy weight of 130lbs.

Subskills: (What are the most essential things that people successful at weight loss do to achieve their long term (target/skill) goals?):

- Dietary Change
- Cardio Exercise
- Slow Cadence Weight Training

MEDs: (What are the most effective, *repeatable* if possible, ways that people successful at weight loss achieve their short term (subskills) goals?):

- Dietary Change: Consume 30g of protein within 30 minutes of waking up. Ferriss uses protien shakes.
- Cardio Exercise: Run a mile every two days.
- Slow Cadence Weight Training: Five minutes of kettlebell swings twice a week.

#####Work TODO: Mockups, Wireframes & *Marketing Mini Site*
#####Home TODO: App Flow + Research
___
Friday - 7/4
More on Marketing

As far as marketing goes, I think that the two most important things are SEO and "Hustle". Hustle is the legwork of networking and gathering users. SEO is the automation that you can "set up" to gain users.

As for SEO i'll be reading - The Art of SEO, 2nd ed.

Also this:
http://www.apptamin.com/blog/create-your-apps-website-before-your-first-line-of-code/

...speaks for itself.

Thursday - 7/3
App Flow

Just transferring paper notes now...
Some slogans:
"Learn more, do less"
"A framwork for rapid skill aquisition"
"An api for life"

I was pretty fond of the last one, so It kind of spurred an idea. What if we split Curve into two parts a la an api and a program made with it. Obviously we cannot make it "cheesily" code based: deconstructSkill(); but I believe it would be intelligent to nod our head to successful APIs and the ways that they are put together.

In my head, the framework is comprise of two things the interactive skill interface and the educative element (the docs). The two will play heavily off of eachother, especially from interface -> docs. I decided that we will let users take care of any subject specific material, we will really only provide resources on the "meta" of it all. In this way, users must be able to use MED's or Subskills that belong to other users. Another cool thing would be for any changes or material by users to be commited to the docs immediately (async w/ Meteor!). So that the docs contain both the "meta-learning" info and material/best practices organized by subject. Anything inputted by the user will be "highly modualar" and availible for use by the community.

As far as what goes into the docs, I imagine in the vein of APIs we have sections and forms of usage (predetermined "methods" - models, heuristics, best practices and/or just general info). For example under the "Deconstruction" section we could have various models and their usages to create MEDs, and under "Target Application Level" we just have a definition and examples. Examples will be key for all.

Some thoughts on Skill defining for the user, we should have a Subject, Skill, Target approach. That is: what general catagory the skill falls under, what the skill is (two nouns out), what the user's target application is. Ex: Programming, "I want to learn server-side code", "I want to make a multi-user prototype of the Curve web app with Meteor.js (MEAN)".

Some thoughts on the opt in. We will have Closed Alpha and Open Beta for the stages of user "population"/bug fixes and subject specific content creation. Users that opt in within the mini site period will be invited to closed alpha, a basic features and information prototype. It is very important that they are introduced as the "first" that matter very much, we need to build a strong community or power users. Open Beta will be an open beta, with all of the three goals in mind, but with user leniency (they are scouting for bugs and creating content) and new alpha-distinct features.

This is important: http://zenhabits.net/top-20-motivation-hacks-19/

Zen Habits is another phenominal source along with the Minimalists for blog style RSA. They should be added as a close second to Ferriss and Kaufman

Another good resource to view marketing, apps, website setup: https://news.ycombinator.com/show
Almost better than HackerNews: http://www.producthunt.com/

Fantastic: http://blog.frontapp.com/hacker-news-techcrunch-and-product-hunt-which-is-most-effective-to-launch-your-product-2/

Awesome: http://goodui.org/

Back to research:

From the Handbook of Expert...

Cruve docs will essentially be a "knowledge base" as defined in Expert Systems (91). It will encompass factual knowledge about meta-learning, but its focus will be heuristic knowledge or flipping heuristics into facts (like Munger with his models). This knowledge is, "experiental, more judgemental [intuition-al] knowledge of performance. Rarely discussed and largely individualistic." This is the cornerstone of Curve, to illicit heuristic knowledge from users about skills and help others to apply this knowledge. "It is knowledge of good practice, good judgement, and plausible reasoning within the domain. It is the knowledge that underlies the art of good guessing."

"Experience is a prerequisite to human expertise... expertise gained through experience can be codified in the knowledge base as rules, heuristics, definitions, taxonomies, prototypes, statstics of prior associations [and] previously solved cases."

When I am ready to actually design the knowledge base, I need to come back to Part 3 (127) and basically read the book from there.

So far we have:

Skill Declaration

(Subject, Skill, Target)

"A problem well stated is a problem half solved"

Docs: Lovability of skill choice

Deconstruction

(Distilling expertise - Finding other's "best practices", Defining subskills (What are the essential in between steps, subjects, ect, NOUN CENTRIC) these are a distillation of the actions (VERB CENTRIC - best practices) of the experts)

Selection

(Deals with thinning out deconstructive research, Grouping and 80/20ing subskills, Formation of your "best practices" on for each subskill (MEDs). (Actionable steps to achieve subskills, VERB CENTRIC))

What is common among best performers, infrequently taught and accords with personal strenghts.

Sequencing

(Deals with ordering "best practices", frequency, habits, feedback loops, practice periods, selecting tools)

Docs: willpower as a muscle, ZenHabits

Stakes

(Deals with commitment and end product)

As for major resources we have at our disposal: Kaufman, Ferriss, Duhigg, Ericsson.

A note on the "rapidity" of this system, it is not defined by hours or time. The only goal we have is to meet the sweet spot between time and aquisition based on your target. The curve is different for all people and all subjects. We do not encourage you to set the bar low or shoot for the stars, rather set a realistic goal and go for it.

An example of MEDs, subskills, and targets

Subject: Fitness

Skill: Weight Management

Target: I want to get back down to my pre pregancy weight of 130lbs.

Subskills: (What are the most essential things that people successful at weight loss do to achieve their long term (target/skill) goals?):

  • Dietary Change
  • Cardio Exercise
  • Slow Cadence Weight Training

MEDs: (What are the most effective, repeatable if possible, ways that people successful at weight loss achieve their short term (subskills) goals?):

  • Dietary Change: Consume 30g of protein within 30 minutes of waking up. Ferriss uses protien shakes.
  • Cardio Exercise: Run a mile every two days.
  • Slow Cadence Weight Training: Five minutes of kettlebell swings twice a week.
Work TODO: Mockups, Wireframes & Marketing Mini Site
Home TODO: App Flow + Research

Friday - 7/4
More on Marketing

As far as marketing goes, I think that the two most important things are SEO and "Hustle". Hustle is the legwork of networking and gathering users. SEO is the automation that you can "set up" to gain users.

As for SEO i'll be reading - The Art of SEO, 2nd ed.

posts.title: Skillgenie 4
posts.markdown:
Monday, July 7th
Worked on Mini-Site

___

Tuesday, July 8th
Kaufman Readthrough

I want to read through the Kaufman & Ferriss resources one more time before I move on totally to hard research and the like. I would like to make sure that all app flow steps have the most helpful parts from each 4HC & First 20. The major feature list is on Thursday in the last post, this is merely "the leftovers".

Keep in mind that the resources will come back into play when the "docs" are generated, for now we need basic skeleton features.

>“That’s not to discount the value of what Ericsson calls “deliberate practice”: intentionally and “systematically practicing in order to improve a skill. Deliberate practice is the core of skill acquisition. The question is how much deliberate practice is required to reach your goal. Usually, it’s much less than you think.”


####Skill Selection
TSL - What does good enough look like? What level realistically would you like the be able to perform the skill at?
####Deconstruction
Kaufman & Ferriss reccomend 3 classic, accessible, complete overview sources. What reoccurs?

3 sources: Subject (Broad), Skill (Focused) & TSL (Narrow)

For ways of deconstruction: Kaufman 76
####Selection
"Learning just enough about each subskill independantly (subject-independant) to check its importance, select whether or not it "matters", then to be able to practice intelligently and self-correct"

Absolute minimum amount of MEDs, try for 3 or 4. Remember Subskill is noun, MED is prescribed practice technique(s) for that skill.

80/20 Subskills: Which skills can I aquire in the least amount of time for the greatest return. Eliminate "noncritical" subskills based on your TSL. Eliminate subskills that have a significant learning curve/barriers or break them down further.


####Sequencing
####Stakes
####Post-Structural (Using the Framework)
Practicing MEDs (Quantity < Quality & Speed)
Self-Monitoring, Adjusting Framework as Needed
####Docs
Aquisition vs Learning, Kaufman 30
Anticipating Barriers, Kaufman 53
___

Wednesday, July 9th
Ferriss Readthrough

Also, worked on mini site.

####Skill Selection
Example: Subject - Language/Japanese
Skill - Writing Kanji
TSL - I want to how to write the basic joyo kanji.

####Deconstruction
Compression takes place ("removal of options").
####Selection
What did you write on your compression "one pager?" this is what should be focused on for MED.
####Sequencing
Most essential, basic, easy skills first. To limit possiblilty of failure.

Frequency: Can I cram or do I need prolonged practice?
####Stakes
Make it painful
####Post-Structural (Using the Framework)
Encoding
####Docs
___

Thursday, July 10th

http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2014/07/10/how-to-profit-from-selling-digital-products-part-1/
Nathan Berry & the Fizzle Guys (Corbett Barr & Co.) are ones to watch as far as online marketing goes.

Skeleton Framework is free, Docs + Integrated Framework are not (trial to pay - one time for all updates).

^This is for fully launched state.

Allowing a fixed number into the beta and alpha stages? Pay for "early access" & content generation opportunities?

Mailchimp or https://convertkit.com/features/
for drip emails after sign up.

___

Friday, July 11th
![Example Image](/content/images/2014/Jul/06-tool-usability-500px-opt.jpg)
^this

On the beginning resource selection, the user should be asked whether or not he has experience in this field. If not, the 3 classic resources should go Subject:1, Skill:1, TSL:1. If some experience, Skill:1, TSL:2.

On working out the kinks, I should actually do the process. Because the entire system is basically just a routing of q&a I will do it that way.

Another note on marketing offerings:
Format goes: Stage (Audience, Price) - Offering, Why


1. Opt-In (Validation, Free) - Weekly Updates, Keep Interest/Validate Market
2. Closed Alpha (Users from Opt-In, Free) - Skeleton Framework/Doc Contribution/Weekly Updates, Subject Content Creation/Evangelism
3. Open Beta (All, reduced fixed price) - Integrated Framework Only/Weekly Updates, Working out bugs & same.
4. Full Release (All, skeleton is free/integrated is fixed full price) - Clean polished


Resources & a "works cited" system is essential in tracking the users insights. Should be entered at subskill.


####What does not work:

Subject: Entrepenurship
Skill: Making a web app
**TSL**: I want to make a rapid skill aquisition web app with Meteor.js or another javascript stack, and successfully market it, so that it earns some amount of money.
Experience: Intermediate
Major Resources: (1,2) 

**+ Designing Web Applications, Barry - for Web Apps & Marketing
+ Discover Meteor.js, Coleman & Greif - for Programming the App
+ 4 Hour Chef, Ferriss - for the App's Subject Matter**

###THIS, is far too complicated & "entire project" based.


####This is what works:

Subject: Entrepenurship
Skill: Internet Marketing
TSL: I want to market a small web application and have it successfully earn any amount of money.
Experience: Intermediate
Major Resources: (1,2) 

+ A general internet marketing book
+ A book about marketing web applications
+ A book about marketing web applications


Lesson learned: an entire project often involves more than one skill. This is rapid *skill* aquisition. So no, I wont be doing the process for the skill. However, for things that have a huge learning curve, like making the web app, I will probably use it.

Remember, when the page goes live, so does the email drip campaign. Which means we need to register curvatu.re soon.
___

Saturday, July 12th

After the mini site is all built and mailchimp & anayltics/SEO are set up on the page, which will hopefully be within the next two weeks. There needs to be contact with the people.

Pick 2 large sites to post on (reddit, Hackernews, Lifehacker)
Pick 4 small sites for focused marketing - guestposts, ect

The email campagin and other constant forms of contact will keep them from there.

#####Redo pricing where alpha costs. A 'la kickstarter
^ Gauge interest, light a fire under my ass.

DING DING!
http://www.apptamin.com/blog/get-funding-mobile-app/

posts.markdown:
Tuesday, July 15th

Ideas for Email Campaign/Contact ("Weekly Updates"):

+ No access to HFON - This is a personal blog, to be edited and released later. Thinking = writing for me.

+ However, there should be a part of the website measuring progress (and financial backing while we're at it) via progress bars and visuals (status.xsolla.com) and most importantly a point by point "what happened today". Can be distilled from this blog daily.

+ A weekly complitation of reading, todo and notes (heavily from HFON) in the form of an email - a 'la Farnam Street's Brain Food.


**Skeleton Builds**
(Solo/Friend Testing)

**Alpha** - Skeleton Framework + Meta-Only Docs, Users generate content and provide feedback (Extremely Closed Testing, ~50)

**Beta** - Integrated Framework + Docs, Users generate content and debug (Large Closed Testing, Weekly Rollout of Invites, <300)

**Open** - Integrated Framework + Docs + Community Linkage

The question is, what is the pay structure.

Pre solo testing - Mini site, feelers out (market validation), capture audience.

During solo testing, after a semi-stable alpha build is created, before docs. Create kickstarter (I need you, can't do this alone...)


___
Wednesday, July 16th

####List of things that need to happen before "feelers" go out:
+ Marketing Mini-Site
+ Mockups for Site
+ Integration of Mailchimp/SEO/Analytics
+ 2wks of Mailchimp Drip Campaign (Reward Hooky/Info + Updates)

####Strategies when "feelers" go out:
+ Cold calling & hustle on 2 large sites (reddit & Hacker News) and 8 blogs (equal distribution of small and large - Kaufman, Ferriss, ZenHabits).
	+ What are appropriate cold-calling strategies - for individuals as well-as communities?
+ What other strategies? How do I validate my market in other ways? 
	+ Using AdWords & Keywords via SEO (begin August 1st)
    
    Walling, Ch.2
    
    4HWW, Ferriss
    
    ^ this is about getting users to see the link - not really as hard as you would think.
    
 Walling, Ch.3 - 5
 
 Barry, Ch.7 - 8
    
	^ this is about getting users to become prospects via page design, offerings, copy (having a successful, meaningful conversion rate) - the super hard part.
    
    #Skillgenie
    
    
    
____

Thursday, July 17th

http://www.usuallypragmatic.com/2014/07/slow-and-steady-is-bullshit.html
^goldmine

Created skillgenie logo (pixel art, pixel over)

___
Friday, July 18th

Worked on site.

___
Saturday, July 19th

Completed site.

Notes on Pricing:

Pre-Alpha (Skeleton Builds): Friends & Me, Skeleton App Coding + Meta Docs

Alpha: 100 from Opt-In - Free Forever, Skeleton App Testing + Subject Based Content Generation (Docs)

Beta: <300 from Kickstarter - Reduced Full Price (1yr), Integrated App Testing + Subject Based
Content Generation (Docs)

Gold: All

+ Full price/yr: Integrated Framework
	+ All updates, "Full experience", Community and Docs (Meta + Subject Based) Integration
+ Free: Skeleton Framework
	+ Standalone, Core updates, no docs or community integration (you can still use both seperately)


KICKSTARTER

+ Thank You - Postcard
+ Gold Access
+ Gold Access for Life (Limited)
+ Beta Key (Limited)
+ Beta Key + Full Reference/Sources (Limited)
+ 3 Beta Keys + Full Reference/Sources + Other Large Reward (Extremely Limited)

posts.title: Skillgenie 6
posts.markdown:
Monday, July 21st
Wireframes & Mockup 1

___

Tuesday, July 22nd
Mockup 2 & Mockup 3


___

Wednesday, July 23rd
Keywords and Final Mockups + Timeline

Bought domian, sent out site to friends for proofing.

To find keywords, since I was not able to locate any product exactly like mine nor a keyword that accurately represented it, I had to look to my competition. 

I used a few of these tools to gather the most popular terms that they use. 
http://www.searchenginejournal.com/5-free-tools-for-competitor-keyword-research/

Competition is as follows:
How-To Sites: wiki how, how to geek
Rapid Learning Liturature: Kaufman, Ferriss
Self-Education Sites: coursera, khan academy

**Keywords follow:**

self development
how to learn
meta learning
online learning
accelerated learning
how to learn fast
how to learn anything
learn anything
learn fast

action-noun-descriptor:
learn skills fast

or 
one keyword from each side of the app, then target whichever one performs better. Ex:

how to learn
aquire skills

####Test 3 keywords: two on opposite "sides of the site" & one super specific:
For example:

+ how to learn anything (framework/how to)
+ meta learning (docs/educational)
+ aquire skills (specific)

Low competition, ~1000 clickers


**Possible Keywords:**

learning curve
learning manegement system
project based learning
learning resources
experiential learning
learning theories

cognative skills
self development


heuristics

learning strategies
learning methods
learning techniques
accelerated learning techniques
meta learning
how to learn

Also, this may or may not be useful:
http://justinmcgill.net/massive-list-of-web-app-directories-to-promote-your-startup/


____

Thursday, July 24th
SEO (Manipulating Google/More Keywords)

Walling - "PPC is useful only for finding keywords that convert for you."

Here are snippits from "The Art of SEO 2nd ed" that I found helpful:

Uncovering Their Secrets in Ch. 4
+ Meta keywords, meta description, alt text & emphasis



>Create an AdWords campaign and send targeted traffic to your site.

>When someone clicks "Try it" or "Buy Now", track conversions using Google AdWords and notify the prospect that your product is still in development. Ask for their email address so you can notify them when you launch. You may get their email, and you may not. Either way, you should have the conversion goal programmed into AdWords so you know which keyword converted, and you'll be able to see how much money you spent for each conversion.

> 
After sending 100-200 visitors to your site, look at the numbers of "trials" or "purchases." Assume you will convert between 2% and 5% of people who clicked "try now" or "download free trial." Assume 40% of the people who clicked "buy now" would have completed the purchase.


http://blog.kissmetrics.com/profitable-google-adwords-campaign/

 #8 and down for setting up adwords tracking.
 Do I need additional analytics?
 
Ch 4,6 & 10 in ART OF...

http://www.keywordspy.com/

August 1st: Adwords campaign and conversion tracking begins. Feelers out (seeking linkage & traffic from other sites using "app directories", social media & blog reachout/guest posting).


Signed up for Google Anayltics and implimented it in the page.


____

Friday, July 25th

Implimented Mailchimp


Good for Pre/Post Alpha:

http://fourhourworkweek.com/2014/07/21/harrys-prelaunchr-email/

http://fourhourworkweek.com/2012/12/18/hacking-kickstarter-how-to-raise-100000-in-10-days-includes-successful-templates-e-mails-etc/

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/zachallia/soma-beautifully-innovative-all-natural-water-filt

Remember: Currently we are validating, not trying to procure a large user base. That comes after the "prototype" to use soma's words.
posts.html:
Monday, July 21st
Wireframes & Mockup 1

Tuesday, July 22nd
Mockup 2 & Mockup 3

Wednesday, July 23rd
Keywords and Final Mockups + Timeline

Bought domian, sent out site to friends for proofing.

To find keywords, since I was not able to locate any product exactly like mine nor a keyword that accurately represented it, I had to look to my competition.

I used a few of these tools to gather the most popular terms that they use.
http://www.searchenginejournal.com/5-free-tools-for-competitor-keyword-research/

Competition is as follows:
How-To Sites: wiki how, how to geek
Rapid Learning Liturature: Kaufman, Ferriss
Self-Education Sites: coursera, khan academy

Keywords follow:

self development
how to learn
meta learning
online learning
accelerated learning
how to learn fast
how to learn anything
learn anything
learn fast

action-noun-descriptor:
learn skills fast

or
one keyword from each side of the app, then target whichever one performs better. Ex:

how to learn
aquire skills

Test 3 keywords: two on opposite "sides of the site" & one super specific:

For example:

  • how to learn anything (framework/how to)
  • meta learning (docs/educational)
  • aquire skills (specific)

Low competition, ~1000 clickers

Possible Keywords:

learning curve
learning manegement system
project based learning
learning resources
experiential learning
learning theories

cognative skills
self development

heuristics

learning strategies
learning methods
learning techniques
accelerated learning techniques
meta learning
how to learn

Also, this may or may not be useful:
http://justinmcgill.net/massive-list-of-web-app-directories-to-promote-your-startup/

Thursday, July 24th
SEO (Manipulating Google/More Keywords)

Walling - "PPC is useful only for finding keywords that convert for you."

Here are snippits from "The Art of SEO 2nd ed" that I found helpful:

Uncovering Their Secrets in Ch. 4
+ Meta keywords, meta description, alt text & emphasis

Create an AdWords campaign and send targeted traffic to your site.

When someone clicks "Try it" or "Buy Now", track conversions using Google AdWords and notify the prospect that your product is still in development. Ask for their email address so you can notify them when you launch. You may get their email, and you may not. Either way, you should have the conversion goal programmed into AdWords so you know which keyword converted, and you'll be able to see how much money you spent for each conversion.

After sending 100-200 visitors to your site, look at the numbers of "trials" or "purchases." Assume you will convert between 2% and 5% of people who clicked "try now" or "download free trial." Assume 40% of the people who clicked "buy now" would have completed the purchase.

http://blog.kissmetrics.com/profitable-google-adwords-campaign/

#8 and down for setting up adwords tracking. Do I need additional analytics?

Ch 4,6 & 10 in ART OF...

http://www.keywordspy.com/

August 1st: Adwords campaign and conversion tracking begins. Feelers out (seeking linkage & traffic from other sites using "app directories", social media & blog reachout/guest posting).

Signed up for Google Anayltics and implimented it in the page.

Friday, July 25th

Implimented Mailchimp

Good for Pre/Post Alpha:

http://fourhourworkweek.com/2014/07/21/harrys-prelaunchr-email/

http://fourhourworkweek.com/2012/12/18/hacking-kickstarter-how-to-raise-100000-in-10-days-includes-successful-templates-e-mails-etc/

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/zachallia/soma-beautifully-innovative-all-natural-water-filt

Remember: Currently we are validating, not trying to procure a large user base. That comes after the "prototype" to use soma's words.

posts.title: Skillgenie 7
posts.markdown:
Hi, this is a combination of the weeks beginning with 7/28 and 8/4. The less docs based research I do, and the more actual "doing" I do, the less I write. I am intent on documenting this process so that A. I can repeat it if need be and B. So that other people can access it. Many of my notes also are on paper, especially wireframes or todos. I mean to get a scanner in September.

Monday, July 28th

Set Up Mailchimp
___
Tuesday, July 29th

Completed Welcome Email

Decided on a manual email campaign. A drip system costs money. Also, we are shooting for continued engagement, not a "soft sell". Theoretically, the product will have already been sold when the user signs up for mail.
___
Wednesday, July 30th

Completed Updates 1 Email
Finalized Keywords

Two things: the Market Validation period and Content marketing. So, instead of doing 100 clicks, we are extending the campagin for a length of time, 2wks @ 7$ per day. 1 wk we will keep the original design and wk 2 we will impliment an updated design.

Keywords need to be carefully measured and weeded out daily.

Content marketing and organic search clicks are the best way to boost SEO. "Masters at Work" section would be fantastic for this. Linkbacks are the best way, but those come as a result of interest in your content. Google Analytics is god.

A 10-15% conversion rate gives us the go ahead to step into the skeleton builds. Trying again with adwords is no big deal, as the lack of conversion could be a result of innacurate keywords or an unappealing landing page. I'd say 2, 2wk @ 7$/day trys is the limit.

Alpha invites need to come out on a rolling basis. The final amount is not a big deal, but the load at a time is what we should be concerned about. We need time to adapt the program and servers to the demand.
___
Thursday, July 31st

Completed Updates 2 Email
___
Friday, August 1st

Launched Adwords Campaign

___
___
Monday, August 4th

Consolidated notes. Recieved my first subscriber!
Began work on Landing v2.0 to launch Saturday.

Various other resources:
http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2014/08/01/the-mathematics-of-discovering-new-things/

http://loganrandolph.com/blog/2014/7/23/vetting-an-idea-in-4-weeks

http://vimeo.com/delvetv

http://www.madrasa.ca/


___
Tuesday, August 5th

Landing v2
___
Wednesday, August 6th

Landing v2: Git commit list
___
Thursday, August 7th

Finished Landing v2, Updated Keywords
___
Friday, August 8th

Sent welcome email out. Taking a well deserved rest!
