posts.title: Skillgenie 8
posts.markdown:
Monday, August 11th Web App Basics, "Freemium" Business Model & Target Conversion Rates Today I studied wed app basics in a "full stack" Javascript context with the first of the following resources: * Learning Web Application Development, Purewal * Your First Meteor Application, Turnbull * Node for Front End Developers, Means * Mongo DB, The Definitive Guide, Chodorow * Javascript Web Applications, MacCaw * Discover Meteor, Greif * Designing Web Applications, Barry I drew a nice little diagram detailing the relationship between server side, client side, MVC and example resources and keywords for both. A little more research on conversion rates and freemium buisness models, just because I'd rather not be dead in the water before I begin building. Here's what I'm thinking: Hosted Web Application (SaaS) "Freemium", Free - Silver - Gold w/ a yearly fee > If your price point is in what I refer to as the consumer range of $ 1 to $50 and your product is priced appropriately for your market, your conversion rate should be between 1% and 4%. [south of .5% is bad] - Walling > Freemium only works when you’re going after a huge market, which is why the most successful freemium companies like Dropbox and Evernote offer solutions targeted at large, horizontal markets. By pricing something of value at zero, you’ve anchored your paid product price to a low number, making it hard to charge a significant amount. You’ve also cannibalized potential customers by offering them a free alternative. Because a large percentage of users are free, it often takes millions of users to build a sizeable number of paying customers. Most freemium companies have customer conversion rates of between 1 percent and 10 percent (with the average around 2 percent to 4 percent). A typical customer also rarely pays more than a few hundred dollars per year. So if you want to build a $100 million annual revenue company, this implies that you likely need to reach many millions of users (see example below). If your market isn’t that big, you shouldn’t be building a freemium company. http://techcrunch.com/2012/11/04/should-your-startup-go-freemium/ Here's another good source http://www.quora.com/Whats-the-average-freemium-conversion-rate-of-consumer-web-apps > Freemium is a marketing strategy, not a revenue model http://blog.priceintelligently.com/blog/bid/159885/Forget-Freemium-Why-It-s-Killing-Your-Pricing-Strategy http://www.totango.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/2012-SaaS-Conversions-Benchmark2.pdf Keep in mind that conversion rates are conversion to free customers, those are usually around 1 to 5%. Above are some industry averages. Analysis of the no credit card SaaS: 10000 visitors - 1000% 1000 signups - 10% 150 paid (conversion) - 1.5% In conclusion, I'll shoot a little below average because PPC advertising will convert less than content marketing or linkbacks. If I get below 8% signup, I need to pivot. If I get upwards of that, it's a go. It is to be determined whether I will let the ad run for the month or for 200 clicks. 100 would give inaccurate data. Or, I go headstrong into development and marketing because I believe that my idea is one of a kind and PPC doesn't do it justice. Here are a few websites: for listing startups: http://www.new-startups.com/ a cool masters at work video: http://devour.com/video/the-engraver/ another one: http://vimeo.com/98953952 ___ Tuesday, August 12th submit your startup: http://startuplister.com/ ___ Wednesday, August 13th Willy Site Review Implimentations Stopped Adwords So, I guess I'm just deciding to go with my gut in developing the app. Adwords gave me valuable experience with keywords and PPC (and how its not always the greatest option when you have slim competition). Slim competition is great, but I am counting on the fact that hopefully people exist that are self-learners. I'm not going to stake my life on this app or say it was a waste of time if no one uses it. Decidedly it will be my project coiciding with my "Mind, Logic and Computation" class. As such, we should redefine the app yet again: **Surface**: Aquiring relevant, actionable "skills" *via* the app & docs. **Underlying**: Meta-learning, giving user the capacity for accurate self-study (& general learning) *via* self-report -> analysis by the app & direct reading -> app integration as far as the docs go. So, the community aspect is very secondary, but also *needs* to be present. It's like playing a 200 player game of M&B online vs bots. It's the same game but you want to know you are not the only one living this expeirence. Next step would be to begin development & to define the "Minimum Viable Product". Putting this alpha build out in a full blast marketing effort will be the true test as to whether or not to continue. I guess Beta should be the goal for the class and this MVC - docs should be the goal 1 or 2 weeks into the class. ___ Thursday, August 14th I cant get over the feeling that Meteor.js is a little too hand-holdy. I want to design in something robust, scalable and applicable. So, we're officially not doing Meteor.

Enter M.E.B.N.

**MV || C :** Backbone + Marionette + Require || Node + Express **Database :** MongoDB + Mongoose **Client :** Bootstrap + Handlebars? + JQuery ___ Friday, August 15th Worked on getting a basic Marionette.Backbone view up.
posts.html:
Monday, August 11th

Web App Basics, "Freemium" Business Model & Target Conversion Rates

Today I studied wed app basics in a "full stack" Javascript context with the first of the following resources:

  • Learning Web Application Development, Purewal
  • Your First Meteor Application, Turnbull
  • Node for Front End Developers, Means
  • Mongo DB, The Definitive Guide, Chodorow
  • Javascript Web Applications, MacCaw
  • Discover Meteor, Greif
  • Designing Web Applications, Barry

I drew a nice little diagram detailing the relationship between server side, client side, MVC and example resources and keywords for both.

A little more research on conversion rates and freemium buisness models, just because I'd rather not be dead in the water before I begin building.

Here's what I'm thinking:
Hosted Web Application (SaaS)
"Freemium", Free - Silver - Gold w/ a yearly fee

If your price point is in what I refer to as the consumer range of $ 1 to $50 and your product is priced appropriately for your market, your conversion rate should be between 1% and 4%. [south of .5% is bad] - Walling

Freemium only works when you’re going after a huge market, which is why the most successful freemium companies like Dropbox and Evernote offer solutions targeted at large, horizontal markets. By pricing something of value at zero, you’ve anchored your paid product price to a low number, making it hard to charge a significant amount. You’ve also cannibalized potential customers by offering them a free alternative. Because a large percentage of users are free, it often takes millions of users to build a sizeable number of paying customers. Most freemium companies have customer conversion rates of between 1 percent and 10 percent (with the average around 2 percent to 4 percent). A typical customer also rarely pays more than a few hundred dollars per year. So if you want to build a $100 million annual revenue company, this implies that you likely need to reach many millions of users (see example below). If your market isn’t that big, you shouldn’t be building a freemium company. http://techcrunch.com/2012/11/04/should-your-startup-go-freemium/

Here's another good source
http://www.quora.com/Whats-the-average-freemium-conversion-rate-of-consumer-web-apps

Freemium is a marketing strategy, not a revenue model http://blog.priceintelligently.com/blog/bid/159885/Forget-Freemium-Why-It-s-Killing-Your-Pricing-Strategy

http://www.totango.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/2012-SaaS-Conversions-Benchmark2.pdf

Keep in mind that conversion rates are conversion to free customers, those are usually around 1 to 5%. Above are some industry averages.

Analysis of the no credit card SaaS:
10000 visitors - 1000%
1000 signups - 10%
150 paid (conversion) - 1.5%

In conclusion, I'll shoot a little below average because PPC advertising will convert less than content marketing or linkbacks. If I get below 8% signup, I need to pivot. If I get upwards of that, it's a go.

It is to be determined whether I will let the ad run for the month or for 200 clicks. 100 would give inaccurate data.

Or, I go headstrong into development and marketing because I believe that my idea is one of a kind and PPC doesn't do it justice.

Here are a few websites:
for listing startups: http://www.new-startups.com/
a cool masters at work video: http://devour.com/video/the-engraver/
another one:
http://vimeo.com/98953952

Tuesday, August 12th

submit your startup: http://startuplister.com/

Wednesday, August 13th

Willy Site Review Implimentations
Stopped Adwords

So, I guess I'm just deciding to go with my gut in developing the app. Adwords gave me valuable experience with keywords and PPC (and how its not always the greatest option when you have slim competition). Slim competition is great, but I am counting on the fact that hopefully people exist that are self-learners. I'm not going to stake my life on this app or say it was a waste of time if no one uses it. Decidedly it will be my project coiciding with my "Mind, Logic and Computation" class.

As such, we should redefine the app yet again:

Surface: Aquiring relevant, actionable "skills" via the app & docs. Underlying: Meta-learning, giving user the capacity for accurate self-study (& general learning) via self-report -> analysis by the app & direct reading -> app integration as far as the docs go.

So, the community aspect is very secondary, but also needs to be present. It's like playing a 200 player game of M&B online vs bots. It's the same game but you want to know you are not the only one living this expeirence.

Next step would be to begin development & to define the "Minimum Viable Product". Putting this alpha build out in a full blast marketing effort will be the true test as to whether or not to continue. I guess Beta should be the goal for the class and this MVC - docs should be the goal 1 or 2 weeks into the class.

Thursday, August 14th

I cant get over the feeling that Meteor.js is a little too hand-holdy. I want to design in something robust, scalable and applicable. So, we're officially not doing Meteor.

Enter M.E.B.N.

MV || C : Backbone + Marionette + Require || Node + Express

Database : MongoDB + Mongoose

Client : Bootstrap + Handlebars? + JQuery

Friday, August 15th

Worked on getting a basic Marionette.Backbone view up.

posts.title: Skillgenie 9
posts.markdown:
Combinitation of the weeks in August beginning with 8/18 and 8/25. Massive research blogging to come as we begin my "Mind, Logic and Computation" course.


Monday 8/18
Require JS

Tuesday 8/19
Grasping MVC

Wednesday 8/20

Focus at large of Skillgenie:

Why is it, that in this day and age where most all information is accessible free of charge, do we depend on others to give it to us?

Now for the first time in history, self learning is accessible and acceptable for a high, professional level of learning. If education can be accepted online, and the classroom can be in your home, on your terms, so can the applicable information.

This is escpecially viable for "portfolio-based" careers, where the only experience that matters is what you do, not who you know or where you've been. If you can produce enough high quality work, then you can most certainly hold a job in that position.

It is time to take your education out of the hands of others and into your own.

Embark with me on my journey to prove the system & this argument, I will spend 3 months learning how to cartoon from the ground up and then apply for an entry level position that often requires other education or experience.

Thursday 8/21, Friday 8/22, Saturday 8/23

On and off Marionette.Backbone work, still trying to get the handle on the whole "web application flow". Working on a basic application where users can add, edit, delete and order info associted with thier account. General, right? 

Also working on hairbydesiree.com, that's been eating up most of my time. Definitly honing my JQuery chops with that one.

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/08/140808111931.htm

http://www.farnamstreetblog.com/2014/08/the-common-pattern-to-procrastination/


Week of the 25th

Began school, fiddling with Require JS, finishing hairbydesiree.com

http://www.launchingnext.com/

posts.title: Skillgenie - Fall 2014 [Meta]
posts.markdown:
This post marks the beginning of the Fall 2014 semester at Loyola Marymount University and my independant study with Dr. Ray Toal titled "Mind, Logic and Computation".


All posts ordered from most recent to least can be seen  [here](http://headfullofnothing.com/tag/mlc/). The post can also be accessed by clicking on the green "MLC" link on the homepage.


##Requirements:
- Bi-Weekly Meetings 

- **Weekly posts** detailing "what I did all week".

- Two classic textbooks in the subject area.

`Computability & Logic // Boolos & Burgess`

- Two professional-oriented books.

`Godel, Escher, Bach // Hofstadter` 

`The Mind’s I // Hofstadter & Dennett`

`Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking // Dennett`

- Six "classic" papers from journals or conference proceedings. 
 
- Twenty or so encyclopedia articles or longform blog posts on topics in your area.

`Melting Asphalt & other “up and coming” blogs
Bret Victor`

`Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy`
	
- **Answers to 40-60 textbook problems.** Avoid the trivial "Check your Understanding" type of questions that generate one to ten word answers. Half the problems, though, can be of the short answer or "solve a relatively easy math problem" variety; the rest should require 15 or more minutes of thought.

`Logic Problems, Stack Exchange/Quora answers`

- **A book review (3-5 pages)** - Due Sept. 30th

- **A short paper (5-6 pages)** overviewing or summarizing the subject area. Cover the major players in the field and the current uses of the technology today. - Due Oct. 30th
    
- **A longer paper (10 pages)** in which you describe one of the problems you are working on in your project. The paper will have code fragments in it. - Due Nov. 30th

- **A project, and associated documentation (top-level architecture diagrams, etc.)**

`Several views in the Skillgenie interface, written in full-stack Javascript.`

- A reading list, in bibliography format, of 40 or so sources that are important in your area.


- An end of the semester **portfolio**



##Assorted Thoughts:
Interested in the relationship btwn intuition pumps, heuristics, logic, mental modals & thinking/learning. Mental latticework, collection of mental structures.

Tracking of/Quantification of these structures. We know that we can express the solution of these in code (sometimes), but can we express the problem or the journey to the solution? Can we create a system that measures human interaction with these structures in order to track, quantify and improve learning?

Metacognition, epsitemology, ontologies of the mind.

posts.title: MLC 3
posts.markdown:
#Assorted Thoughts:
Taking mental models (thinking in general) from the mind into *physical* consciousness, turning them into functional modules that people can use. Imagine the model is a long sequence of framing actions and thoughts, easily screwed up when you are simotainously (and often subconciously) trying to remember the model and validate its use for the particular situation. I'd like to package the models up into little "functions" that people can more or less pass an argument into and recieve the desired output. That way, a overall latticework is created more easily and can be highly modular. Development of highly personalized thinking is easier, and *physically* represented/clear. Enslavement to convoluted and illogical systems of thinking are avoided.

**Dennett, 8** - 
Dennett parses out the parts of the "Whimsical Jailer" intuition pump. This resembles the ability to parse subjects and predicates in logic. Also mentions "going meta", WVO Quine's semnatic ascent.

We are looking at two parts of the study: research and then implimentation of the research into the Skillgenie app. All the while, learning about web app development which is not nessicarily a focus in this study.
___
#Daily:
####Monday, September 1st
Began "Intuition Pumps", created schedule for semester, set initial meeting date.

####Wednesday, September 3rd
Revisited the skeleton Skillgenie app, un-implimented RequireJS, following along with "Backbone.Marionette.js: A Gentle Introduction" by David Sulc.

Attempting to get basic functionailty from the contact app detailed in the book. Users should be able to post, delete, edit and reorder small modules of data. 

Should impliment Handlebars for templating, RequireJS for dependancy mangement and Mongoose for Mongo schemas. This all comes after the basic contact app is made.

Need to impliment spellcheck and better markdown for this theme. I want multi-tiered lists, more obvious `code`.
####Thursday, September 4th
Met with Dr. Toal, discussed the requirements, importance of "strange loops" within metacognition. 

Should refer to:
[On the Nature of Things](http://cs.lmu.edu/~ray/classes/nt/)

[Language, Thought & Computation](http://cs.lmu.edu/~ray/classes/llc/)

for decoding Godel, Escher, Bach and other concepts (logic, ect) within the study.

Encountered these in Interaction Design:
[Mac Human Interface Guidelines](https://developer.apple.com/librarY/mac/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/Intro/Intro.html)

####Friday, September 5th

Thoughts on the interface:

Basic "Skill" view is free to manipulate/organize by the user, could maybe have a few preset ways to organize (timeline, kanban, etc). 

Mental models, tools for thinking enter into the picture via the steps of self-learning (deconstruction, selection, etc). Answering the question of: how do I parse out and utilize the sea of information on this subject? Translating these methods described in prose to an tactile interface or a way of input that guides the self-learning.

Decentralizing education, putting it in the hands of the learner (self-learning). Wealth of information, not enough teachers.
___
posts.html:
Assorted Thoughts:

Taking mental models (thinking in general) from the mind into physical consciousness, turning them into functional modules that people can use. Imagine the model is a long sequence of framing actions and thoughts, easily screwed up when you are simotainously (and often subconciously) trying to remember the model and validate its use for the particular situation. I'd like to package the models up into little "functions" that people can more or less pass an argument into and recieve the desired output. That way, a overall latticework is created more easily and can be highly modular. Development of highly personalized thinking is easier, and physically represented/clear. Enslavement to convoluted and illogical systems of thinking are avoided.

posts.title: MLC 4
posts.markdown:
#Assorted Thoughts:

Program goals by December (skeleton Skillgenie):

* Timeline view: Post/edit/delete/reorder subskills
* Profile/Community view: profile data & how it stacks up vs. others - - "leaderboard" 
	+ vote up & down by catagory and meta - action, learning, etc?

Designing an interface for data entry in such a way that it facilitates learning through: **planning** (user - ability to filter through & manipulate "skill" information), **monitoring** (service - ability to track/quantify the learning process, user - facilitate understanding/interpretation), **evaluating** (user - ability to compare against others & facilitate self-correction).

Study of metacognition underlies a web application.
This is an exercise in "[metacognitive regulation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacognition#Components)".

[This article on "self-regulated" learning](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-regulated_learning) and the above article are hitting the nail **directly** on the head.

In other words, the programming itself will be relatively straight forward. The driving research behind it will be the bulk of the work.

> On the one hand, someone may wonder how we make the journey of learning how to program — in other words how does the programmer know how to program?  How did he or she learn?  What makes those ideas or skills that make the programmer able to write code, that untrained people can’t?  How do you know when to use a function, a for loop, a while loop or whatever?  There is a journey there, I think, in the way you were using the term.

 >On the other, programming itself is a journey.  Programming is designing something.

 > 1) Programming is designing something - the application you want to make happen.

 > 2) But there is a notion of how to design the program itself.

 >Two levels but maybe they are tied together somehow.  Maybe there is a strange loop.



___
#Daily:
Was not able to keep a consistant daily log this week. 

Compiled a broad description/todo of the app (above), worked on the basic web app backend & read Intuition Pumps.

I expect to come into alot of time in October - Early November to construct the app. For now, weekend research and nightly reading.

On the other, programming itself is a journey. Programming is designing something.

Two levels but maybe they are tied together somehow. Maybe there is a strange loop.

posts.title: MLC 5
posts.markdown:
#Assorted Thoughts

Learning process = thinking

Track, quantify & measure thinking in a way short of attatching electrodes to one's brain. 

Stray away from tracking mudane things like time, frequency, etc. Let user submit their own metrics (what way did you do this, how did you feel about doing it this way)

+

Constructing an open framework for this entry of skills (thing to track) and metrics (tracking itself). Making it relatively painless to think about thinking.

Self tracking facilitates self learning. Self learning facilitates improved learning. Improved learning facilitates faster comprehension.

[Deep Learning Bibliography](http://memkite.com/deep-learning-bibliography/)

Thinking about what my goal, with respect to research and my application is, is immensely helpful to me in figuring out concrete steps to lead me. The nature of metacognition is inherintly difficult, because it depends on the thinker being able to grasp his thinking.

I am working on a project at the Academic Resource Center similar, but more narrow than this. It has to do with metacognative processes in writing. I discovered that the motivations behind this and my projects here are the same. Namely, that I do not believe that writing, as well as thinking in general, is some intuitive, mystical skill. Obviously, right? A commonly heard phrase that I like to pair with this thought is when I hear students saying, "well I guess I'm just not a good writer." Bullshit!

Strategies for writing well are never really clear cut, as is a common thread in metacognition, and are difficult to articulate. It often boils down to a tutor saying, "Do this" and a student trying to repeat that specific way. There is a distinct difference between what to write and how to write it. I honestly believe from the bottom of my heart that there is a better way to teach/recieve metacognative processes than merely gleaning from an example. This method also is heavily dependant on the example given, where it the example may not suit the student and then there is nothing gleaned. The opportunities for any self-correction or independant learning of these strategies are close to nil using this method, for the only way that the student can learn more about the process is entirely dependant on more examples or a vague, "no thats not the way to do it". We should be asking why this is the case.

Found this: [The Very Short Teach Yourself Logic Guide](http://www.logicmatters.net/tyl/shorter-tyl/)

Great overview of the many areas of logic and what resources are applicable/give examples/etc.

Will use D3.js for data visualization

Here's another project along the same lines (kind of) as this: [Designing a Personal Knowledgebase](http://www.acuriousmix.com/2014/09/03/designing-a-personal-knowledgebase/)

holistic

philosophical framework on metacognition
one large paper


lower level
related studies comparison

players
perspectives/contrast
exposition
comparison
conclusion

___
####TL;DR:

######2 Views:
Timeline - Data Entry, Manipulation by User
Track - "Thinking Analytics", Comparison, Suggestions

######Guiding Question:
What things (short of measuring brain activity or "train your brain") are trackable/quantifiable about metacognitive *processes*? 

######Goal:
Impliment 3+ metrics (completely! from entry to visualization) for metacognition.

posts.title: MLC 6
posts.markdown:
Combined content for weeks 6 & 7 of the semester.
___
Finished Intuition Pumps, wrote a 5 page book review.

Week 1 of 2 finishing basic Marionette app using Sulc's "Backbone.Marionette.js: A Gentle Introduction"

Aquired some new resources pointed towards a more psychological view of metacognition (a really great overview of the field & all published within the last 4 years):

The Taxonomy of Metacognition by Tarricone
The Philosophy of Metacognition by Proust

Thinking about picking up Language, Cognition, and Human Nature: Selected Articles by Pinker. Now that I have selected my topic of study, I think it is time to reach more deeply into it, especially where it is most developed in psychology.

Also picked up Logic 2nd ed. by Baronett. Excited to work some proofs and brush up on my predicate logic.

As far as the app, I am giving myself another week to play "web app skills" catch up. I am implimenting the contacts app from Sulc as bare-bones as possible, so no accounts, authentication, etc. The goal is such that we can clone it from GitHub and get all of the basic functionality for *one* user. Instead of querying a database for information, I can manufacture JSON data to feed directly into the app. We're shooting for a demo!

After this week, I am giving myself 2 weeks to design the views & data input and then another week to the 1st metric. Granted there will probably be alot of backtracking and spinning my wheels b/c my web app skills are pretty elementary (trying to plan for that).

All my research for the study in the past 2 weeks was focused on Dennett. Watching talks and reading.

___

Mon: Sulc // Routing - Data Latency
Tues: Sulc // Editing a Contact (to 177)
Wednes: Sulc // Complex Views - Filtering Contacts
Thurs: Sulc // About & Header Sub Applications
Fri: Interaction with JSON Data
Sat: Interaction with JSON Data
Sun: Refactor & Absorb (Begin IxD Paper)

posts.title: MLC 7
posts.markdown:
Combined post for Weeks 8 & 9 of the semester.

Completed week 2/2 of Marionette Bootcamp, finished *most* of Sulc's book.

**Computation:** Moving on to "Developing Backbone.js Applications" by Osmani and "Anatomy of a web application using node.js, ExpressJS, MongoDB & Backbone.js" by Krol in an effort to create a RESTful server for Sulc's contact app. I was going to leave json files with the data in the app folders, but going the extra step and putting up a Mongo/Express server would integrate less "cringe-ily" into the app. Sulc was a great intro to MVC and Backbone.Marionette "best practices", Osmani and Krol will handhold me to separating concerns.

I have basic add, edit and delete "skill posts" functionality for the app. We now need the storage of the user data to *not* create an eyesore in the app code (as Sulc's example does). This will involve a lot of detangling in Sulc's Contact app.

Need to implement reorder functionality. All other data used to compose the metrics will be inputted by the user via editing adding and deleting (to begin with).

Repurposing (redesigning) the contact app into Skillgenie will not be difficult, I have wireframes prepared.

>This web app "catch-up" is priority #1 -implementing "reorder" functionality to test drive my Marionette skills & getting Sulc's Contact app integrated with a RESTful API. Then comes implementing the already designed views. The rest is implementing *ways* of user input and metric display, which should become clear with research.
___
**Mind:** Concurrently reading "The Taxonomy of Metacognition", beginning in November a ~15 page paper titled "A Holistic Approach to Measuring Metacognitive Processes". Will seek to knock out the rest of my reading on this topic (between the Wikipedia references and intro books, I should be swimming in journal articles), Dennett was a great warmup to get me focused. This paper will act as quick overview of the area & address the problem.

>This research will begin when I have the basic functionality of the app set up, will be concurrent with my essay writing in November. 

___
**Logic/Computation:**
As far as textbook problems, I feel like 3/4 will be from Baronett's "Logic" book. Most will be predicate logic, i'll ramp up the difficulty as I get going. 1/4 "hard" problems will be from Boolos's "Computability and Logic". I think it would serve me well to focus on logic, StackOverflow Philosophy is a little intimidating. I will continue looking for topics I can provide a little insight on.

>This is low priority, needs to be begun. Setting aside 1 or 2 nights a week should suffice. Going to generate a schedule, maybe coming up with a concept and problem set a week or bi-weekly.

___
####A Primer on Metacognition
___

Addressed indirectly in philosophy as epistemology. Mainly developed in educational and developmental psychology. Term coined by John Flavell in 1979 from "higher level cognition". Processes of the self ("self-monitoring", "self-regulation"). The sub-field of **Metamemory** is what deals with  the "introspective knowledge of one’s own memory capabilities (and strategies that can aid memory) and the processes involved in memory self-monitoring." 
http://ai.ato.ms/MITECS/Entry/moses.html

Checked out "Handbook of Metamemory and Memory" by Dunlosky and Bjork, am finding that the field is pretty young. It also has a very small amount of *experimental* psychological research. Much of the field is theorizing and trying to model these structures. What would be helpful to constructing these metrics for the app would be to find these specific *experiments* that back the research (psychology, dipping into neuroscience) and find what the researchers measured. Flavell's research is carries huge weight, so is Nelson and Naren's 1990 paper. That paper "obtained [metacognition] an identity within the field". I assume by the field they mean cognitive psychology. 

We could split the field into two basic areas: judgement & control processes. Most research looks at how judgment effects control processes (ie. how student's overconfidence leads to detrimental information recall). I feel like the research taken (could be wrong) is based on the judgement, where I need to find studies with experiments rooted in the processes and how they effect judgement (as that is really how the control flow of my app will go. user data - > metrics -> analytics (?)) http://quant5.com/blog/enterprise-analytics/metrics-vs-analytics/


[Evolution of Metacognition, Metcalfe](http://www.columbia.edu/cu/psychology/metcalfe/PDFs/MetcalfeEvolMetacog.pdf)

[Metamemory: A Theoretical Framework and New Findings, Nelson & Narens](http://www.imbs.uci.edu/~lnarens/1990/Nelson&Narens_Book_Chapter_1990.pdf)

[Cool Intro Philosophy Resource](http://introlearn.com/philosophy-main.php)

___

End of Oct. will be spent finalizing basic app functionality & views.

November will be spent finishing research and implimenting metrics.

posts.title: MLC 8
posts.markdown:
####Resource list for RESTful Implementation:
I frequently referred to Andy Osmani's "Developing Backbone.js Applications" as well as various "full-stack" JS examples like Krol's "Contacts App" and Coenraets's "Wine Cellar App".
####Updated tool list (Taken from Krol):

Server (Node + Express)
Data (Mongoose + MongoDB)
MVC (Backbone.Marionette)
Utility (Bower + Grunt + ...

####Unsure about, but here for my disposal:
Browserfy

Front-End Testing (Jasmine + Karma + PhantomJS)
Back-End Testing (Mocha + Chai + Sinon + Proxyquire)

___
#####Development Progress as of November 3rd, Monday

Finished implementing RESTful server & functionality one week ago. Was able to establish additional functionality & design (used this app as boilerplate) in CMSI 370's "RPG Front End" project.

Currently implementing timeline (transforming #contacts) & metric (new) views. Made an executive decision to **not** use D3, although it would be best for scalability. At this point, I am trying to focus on research and implementation with what I am familiar with, rather than taking on more new technology. With this in mind, I will be able to put out a demo app at the end of the semester. Everything will be functioning, however it will be demo-ed by one user and will not be scalable to any user base just yet. 

The underlying research and the **point** I am trying to get across will be conveyed by the demo app. This is my primary focus: that the user will be able to grasp metacognitive data about themselves from simple "skill" data entry. This would hopefully spur the user to change their thinking, although this is not the aim of the initial demo app. My aim is to creatively replicate/reinterpret ways of metacognitive measurement already tested by researchers, and make the resulting data visually accessible to users.

Additionally, I am concurrently working on research in my Philosophy of Science course on metacognition. I am investigating the young field and its causal connections/explanations (if any) with neuroscience. In other words, I am working on a "grounding issue": what implications does it have for metacognition as a discipline that certain theories are/are not/could be grounded in a "lower-level" discipline. You could then proceed to: if they are/are not grounded, then are the models and theories proposed in this area *accurate*

After a cursory look at the field and a few conversations with my PHIL professor, I am convinced this is a relevant problem (that is *actually* talked about) worth pursuing. This question is really what sits at the heart of Skillgenie: the *accurate* representation of mental processes concerning learning.

___

#### Logic Schedule
###### 1 Day per Wk - 1 Chapter - ~10 Problems (Proofs) - Wednesdays & Sundays


Wk 1 - Completed
Baronett - Ch. 8
Catch-Up: All Previous Rules + Conditional & Indirect Proof

Wk 2 - Current
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
B. Four New Rules of Inference
C. Change of Quantifier

Wk 3
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
D. Conditional & Indirect Proof

Wk 4
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
F. Relational Predicates

Wk 5
Boolos - Ch. 9: A Precis of First-Order Logic: Syntax 
Boolos - Ch. 10: A Precis of First-Order Logic: Semantics 

Wk 6
Boolos - Ch. 22: Second Order Logic 

Wk 7
Boolos - Ch. 27: Modal Logic and Provability


Resources were recommended by Dr. Brad Stone in the LMU Philosophy dept. Having taken his class in Symbolic Logic, I am familiar with Baronett's Logic 2nd ed. To further my studies in symbolic logic, with a direction towards CompSci, he recommended Computability and Logic 5th ed. by Boolos, Burgess and Jeffrey.
posts.html:
Resource list for RESTful Implementation:

I frequently referred to Andy Osmani's "Developing Backbone.js Applications" as well as various "full-stack" JS examples like Krol's "Contacts App" and Coenraets's "Wine Cellar App".

Updated tool list (Taken from Krol):

Server (Node + Express)
Data (Mongoose + MongoDB)
MVC (Backbone.Marionette)
Utility (Bower + Grunt + ...

Unsure about, but here for my disposal:

Browserfy

Front-End Testing (Jasmine + Karma + PhantomJS)
Back-End Testing (Mocha + Chai + Sinon + Proxyquire)

Development Progress as of November 3rd, Monday

Finished implementing RESTful server & functionality one week ago. Was able to establish additional functionality & design (used this app as boilerplate) in CMSI 370's "RPG Front End" project.

Currently implementing timeline (transforming #contacts) & metric (new) views. Made an executive decision to not use D3, although it would be best for scalability. At this point, I am trying to focus on research and implementation with what I am familiar with, rather than taking on more new technology. With this in mind, I will be able to put out a demo app at the end of the semester. Everything will be functioning, however it will be demo-ed by one user and will not be scalable to any user base just yet.

The underlying research and the point I am trying to get across will be conveyed by the demo app. This is my primary focus: that the user will be able to grasp metacognitive data about themselves from simple "skill" data entry. This would hopefully spur the user to change their thinking, although this is not the aim of the initial demo app. My aim is to creatively replicate/reinterpret ways of metacognitive measurement already tested by researchers, and make the resulting data visually accessible to users.

Additionally, I am concurrently working on research in my Philosophy of Science course on metacognition. I am investigating the young field and its causal connections/explanations (if any) with neuroscience. In other words, I am working on a "grounding issue": what implications does it have for metacognition as a discipline that certain theories are/are not/could be grounded in a "lower-level" discipline. You could then proceed to: if they are/are not grounded, then are the models and theories proposed in this area accurate

After a cursory look at the field and a few conversations with my PHIL professor, I am convinced this is a relevant problem (that is actually talked about) worth pursuing. This question is really what sits at the heart of Skillgenie: the accurate representation of mental processes concerning learning.

Logic Schedule

1 Day per Wk - 1 Chapter - ~10 Problems (Proofs) - Wednesdays & Sundays

Wk 1 - Completed
Baronett - Ch. 8
Catch-Up: All Previous Rules + Conditional & Indirect Proof

Wk 2 - Current
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
B. Four New Rules of Inference
C. Change of Quantifier

Wk 3
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
D. Conditional & Indirect Proof

Wk 4
Baronett - Ch. 9: Predicate Logic
F. Relational Predicates

Wk 5
Boolos - Ch. 9: A Precis of First-Order Logic: Syntax
Boolos - Ch. 10: A Precis of First-Order Logic: Semantics

Wk 6
Boolos - Ch. 22: Second Order Logic

Wk 7
Boolos - Ch. 27: Modal Logic and Provability

To further my studies in symbolic logic, with a direction towards CompSci, he recommended Computability and Logic 5th ed. by Boolos, Burgess and Jeffrey.

posts.title: MLC 9
posts.markdown:
####Skillgenie App:
#####Basic Views for Timeline & Metric Complete
By weekend, seeking to complete the design and basic implementation for the timeline and metric views.

Metric view will be as complete as I can get it. In the timeline, I can always add more options for data entry. The metric view and how I choose visualize the metrics are highly dependent on how I calculate the data and what I'm calculating. I'm thinking a line graph will represent the basic stuff well enough for now. I'll put that in and make the data modular enough so I can mold it to most forms of visualization.

First order of business with the timeline is to implement: http://www.shindiristudio.com/demo/?item=Content%20Timeline_jQuery

I want the item views currently in the chart to be replaced by the little timeline posts. All of the add, delete, reorder actions must correspond to the dot on the timeline, obviously. This would be a good time to introduce tighter Handlebars.js templating. Edit will be an option confined to the big show view, no more modal. Add will be a separate view or way more detailed modal. Show view (like the RPG) will give a more detailed account of the post.

For the metrics themselves (this is really what the entire app has been building to support), I am searching hard for metacognitive measurements that have to do with cognitive regulation. The commonly measured items have to do with judgement, which seems a little too touchy feely and easy to me. Who knows, upon further investigation this may be the only method of measurement (taking personal judgement against reality) that is valid for metacognition. I will be looking heavily into cognitive neuroscience for tighter methods of measurement. 

___
####Research Log:
#####Working through Phil of Science part of ~15pg "Problem Paper"
#### 11/4
Read through much of Tarricone's "Taxonomy of Metacognition". Initial guiding research question will be: From what, or what is the basis of, these models and theories (represented by the models) that they spawn from. Is it the researcher's experience? Is it experimentation? Or is it good ol' fashion rationalist deduction?

If it is the latter, then we cannot rightly call it science. This can be easily solved by reading the famous papers referred to by Tarricone.

From these papers, we can find the theories in question. It may be that the theories are composed of sub-components that are empirically verifiable (*so meta*).

I would love to champion Metacognition as being a scientific discipline, and as it is primarily grounded in psychology (which straddles the line between hard and soft science), it is very possible. In order to prove this, we need to find examples of empirical measurement from which the theories are deduced from.

The taxonomy developed by Tarricone is incredibly helpful in deciphering the terminology and connections in the field. 

Two additional books that I am beginning with, in addition to google searches, database searches and reference (bibliography) hunting are The Cognitive Neuroscience of Metacognition by Fleming and Frith, and The Philosophy of Metacognition by Proust.

**There are really two dimensions here, getting a grasp of the "grounding" issue (philosophically and how it crops up within research) and seeing if it can be solved (measurement).**

As a jump off point for measurement, I think the Fleming volume will be great. For general terms and layout, Tarricone. And for a grasp of the prevailing philosophical views about the discipline and representation, Proust. 

Metric-centric Keywords:
cognitive monitoring
cognitive regulation

#### 11/7

Dug into the the general "Philosophy of Science" issue a little more, which is: can we consider cognitive psychology an semantically autonomous discipline?

Necessarily, this is the heart of the issue. Looking at an early version of how my "problem" paper will be structured:

+ Brief introduction of the discipline
+ *Description of the goal for the app, why? What is the problem at the surface?
+ Explanation of the underlying philosophical problem.
___
+ Position A: Reductionism
+ Position B: Non-reductionism (grants explanatory autonomy)
+ *Implications of autonomous psychology for the app.
___

+ Affirmation of the reductionist position. Specifically, how quantification/computation (measurement, development of metrics) affirms the position.
	+ Methods of quantification for metacognition (Huge.)
+ *What I did specifically to measure metacognition.
	+ Interesting takes on replicating experiments, what methods are more valid than others in the constraints of a web app?
	+ Addressing specifics of the app (design choices, technology choices)
    
I have a growing list of articles and books that deal with this issue in varying capacities, I will make sure to include the important ones as I continue the research log.

posts.title: About
posts.markdown:
#About >As the geometer, who endeavours
To square the circle, and discovers not, By taking thought, the principle he wants, >Even such was I at that new apparition;
I wished to see how the image to the circle Conformed itself, and how it there finds place. > *Canto XXXIII, Paradiso, Dante Aligheri* ![](/content/images/2015/Jan/3741213-1.jpg) My name is Jackson Souza, I am new graduate and yet another proud California to Washington transplant. Contrary to many career programmers and akin to many computer scientists, I prefer the esoteric over the useful, the difficult to the trivial, and the complex over the simple. As such, it might seem counterintuitive to begin this page with a verbose quote from a forgotten book of a medieval poet, because verbose and forgotten are just the words I *don't* want describing my work. With a nod towards these confusing levels of abstraction, my code as well as my writing tends to be careful, organic, academic and above all, succinct. The purpose of this blog is to host my development outlines/logs, any longform writing that I do, and my portfolio of work. The development stuff is a peek inside my head, and my brain is certainly no Hemingway. In this regard, I often move quickly from one project to the next so, please excuse spelling and non-coherency. Rest assured that all portfolio and longform items can be held to a higher standard of writing. Thank you & enjoy! ## About Me In May (2015), I graduated from Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, CA with a degree in Philosophy and minor in Computer Science. I completed a large body of work on the *leitmotiv* of light in medieval philosophy, culminating a BA thesis and an eqivalent project in Computer Science rooted in machine learning and EdTech. I wouldn't say that these subjects define me, but not including my reigning interests for the past 4 years would render this description incomplete. Specifically, my current interests, not exclusive to academia, include the [autonomy of psychology](http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/scientific-unity/#ConWhyUniWhaDifDoeItReaMak), [light metaphysics](http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/grosseteste/#MetLig), machine learning in Python, [banjo](http://youtu.be/N49k4KkshAs) and my 6 mo. old kitten, Wednesday. ##"Head Full of Nothing"? I don't know. I remember singing this one with some buddies at a festival in Santa Barbara. This page was done in the style of one of my favorite blogs written by Kevin Simler, [*Melting Asphalt*](http://www.meltingasphalt.com/). This blog was adapted from a Ghost.js theme made by PixelUnion, "Readymade Lite".
posts.html:
About

As the geometer, who endeavours
To square the circle, and discovers not,
By taking thought, the principle he wants,

Even such was I at that new apparition;
I wished to see how the image to the circle
Conformed itself, and how it there finds place.

Canto XXXIII, Paradiso, Dante Aligheri

My name is Jackson Souza, I am new graduate and yet another proud California to Washington transplant.

Contrary to many career programmers and akin to many computer scientists, I prefer the esoteric over the useful, the difficult to the trivial, and the complex over the simple. As such, it might seem counterintuitive to begin this page with a verbose quote from a forgotten book of a medieval poet, because verbose and forgotten are just the words I don't want describing my work. With a nod towards these confusing levels of abstraction, my code as well as my writing tends to be careful, organic, academic and above all, succinct.

The purpose of this blog is to host my development outlines/logs, any longform writing that I do, and my portfolio of work. The development stuff is a peek inside my head, and my brain is certainly no Hemingway. In this regard, I often move quickly from one project to the next so, please excuse spelling and non-coherency. Rest assured that all portfolio and longform items can be held to a higher standard of writing. Thank you & enjoy!

About Me

In May (2015), I graduated from Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, CA with a degree in Philosophy and minor in Computer Science. I completed a large body of work on the leitmotiv of light in medieval philosophy, culminating a BA thesis and an eqivalent project in Computer Science rooted in machine learning and EdTech.

I wouldn't say that these subjects define me, but not including my reigning interests for the past 4 years would render this description incomplete. Specifically, my current interests, not exclusive to academia, include the autonomy of psychology, light metaphysics, machine learning in Python, banjo and my 6 mo. old kitten, Wednesday.

"Head Full of Nothing"?

I don't know. I remember singing this one with some buddies at a festival in Santa Barbara.

This page was done in the style of one of my favorite blogs written by Kevin Simler, Melting Asphalt.

This blog was adapted from a Ghost.js theme made by PixelUnion, "Readymade Lite".

posts.title: Xsolla
posts.markdown:
######Look at how much the cast of Glee loves Xsolla:
![](/content/images/2015/Jan/glee.jpg)

Xsolla is a "cross-platform payment and billing solution for improving monetization and conversion for games." Where Stripe, PayPal and similar companies handle a select few parts of the payment process, Xsolla seeks to provide solutions from end to end. 

To unpack that a little more, a full use of Xsolla's services, say for an indie game with green developers, might provide marketing, implementation of in-game purchases, payment handling, processing, billing and payment localization. With offices in Russia, Brazil, Korea and Los Angeles, localization is Xsolla's biggest draw. Indie devs seeking to expand their audience globally, from no audience at all, would be *the* target customer. Where things get interesting is Xsolla's partnership with many recognizable players in the gaming industry. Marketplaces & companies like Valve's Steam, Twitch, Wargaming, EA's Humble Bundle & Ubisoft all depend on Xsolla in one capacity or another to facilitate payment from their players.

As far as my role in the company, I was initially tasked with implementing designs for targeted landing pages. Interestingly enough, the designers & back-end developers were located in Perm, Russia. My various other projects, like constructing data visualization displays in the office, line editing (for English), helping to develop documentation for the API, and implementing new designs on the company website always involved back and forth negotiations between time zones. Let's just say that Skype & JIRA were essential. 

![](/content/images/2015/Jan/workspace.jpg)

It was an amazing opportunity to work as a web development intern here. This relatively small company has really "set the benchmark" for me in terms of the atmosphere in which I would like to work. In addition to receiving comprehensive instruction on secure and agile development via the senior developers, I was able to have daily interaction with upper management. This open communication style within the company aided my proactive mindset, as much of the time I was left to my own devices, always seeking a new project or improvement.






#####Marketing/Localization/Web
+ *Implemented function & design for Xsolla [CEO](http://landing.xsolla.com/ceo/), [CFO](http://landing.xsolla.com/cfo/), & [CTO](http://landing.xsolla.com/cto/) landing pages.
+ Implemented Chinese localization for landing pages
+ *Function & design edits on [API](http://developers.xsolla.com/) & [Home](http://xsolla.com/) site
+ Revised English for xsolla.com & the Xsolla API (may be depreciated)
+ Created Xsolla account statement templates

#####Integration/Back-End
+ Received extensive instruction on Xsolla workplace technologies and various development technologies from Tom Murray 
	+ JIRA, LDAP, Gitlab, Github, Xsolla API, PHP, Local Development Environment in 	WAMP, Javascript, HTML, CSS, Bash
+ Implemented WP localization plugin site-wide to allow multi-language localization

#####IT/Misc
+ Prepared desktop computers for new hires
+ Prepared laptops & transitioned data for internationally traveling co-workers
+ *Constructed Raspberry Pi Data Visualization wall & implemented all software, hardware, networking and 			documentation
+ Maintained server/network equipment
+ Assisted new hires in learning Xsolla workplace technologies: JIRA, LDAP 

#####Supervisors: Ulyana Chernyak & *Tom Murray

posts.title: L.A. Girlfriend
posts.markdown:
>Influenced by the post-punk and no wave movements of the 80s, L.A. Girlfriend explores the darker side of love while maintaining a romantic and youthful spirit toward the subject. Through the marriage of analog and digital elements, the synth-pop brain child of front woman Sydney Banta hides emotionally telling stories with danceable melodies worthy of mending any broken heart. Razor-sharp, yet charmingly sweet, L.A. Girlfriend proves that rejection can be a beautiful thing.

####Pt. 1: Musical Involvement

In an effort to expand her then solo project to greater heights, Sydney brought me on in late 2012. At this early stage in our musical partnership, I was able to perform her computer oriented music through my experience in DAW audio programs and MIDI, leaving her more space to sing and play bass guitar. 

![](/content/images/2015/Jan/542884_424717750875165_1820887054_n.jpg)


The bulk of my time spent in LAGF was that of a musically contributing member, helping to record the VIVA record and compose various EPs & remixes. We also began to look into expanding the project further, bringing on a bass player momentarily and a steady drummer. As LAGF grew, I began to shape the live set around the mainly computer based music. At the height of the project, we were able to skillfully integrate both computers & traditional instruments, which Sydney still continues to do today.


<iframe style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align:center;"  width="100%" height="166" scrolling="no" frameborder="no" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/65250545&color=ff5500&auto_play=false&hide_related=false&show_comments=true&show_user=true&show_reposts=false"></iframe>

<iframe style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align:center;" width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/hrf-5cwcKtY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

####Pt. 2: Web Development
As I became more skilled in web development, Sydney approached me about taking charge of our online presence. Truth be told, she commands social media marketing like nobody's business, but Sydney lacked the skills to effectively implement her designs on the web. Together, we drafted a site that would be able to aggregate photos, music, tour dates and contact information in a style that would concur with the LAGF aesthetic. The site was done with no Bootstrap templating, completely in JQuery, utilizing multiple side scrolling libraries for touch, images and "pages".

Please refer to the portfolio page for screenshots. Currently, Sydney hosts lagirlfriendmusic.com as a Squarespace site, so that she can manage the information herself.

![](/content/images/2015/Jan/1069914_569307383132384_913279787_n.jpg)

posts.title: Skillgenie
posts.markdown:
Latest Build: https://damp-depths-5898.herokuapp.com/

If we take the traditional academic system of learning, in which a student is presented with information, applies the information, then receives feedback on their application; the entire process spans a large amount of time. This system requires multiple people, in an often non-ideal environment, with an ever dwindling pool of resources. If we look at learning outside of traditional education, there are many resources that meet specific informational needs. This mirrors K-12 education, where classes only exist on the merit of their content. Despite this, arguably the most important thing one learns in school is not the specifics of dead presidents and algebra, but how to internalize the information.

Skillgenie is a platform that facilitates independent education, completely apart from the specifics of the information. At its core, the app creates a habitual feedback loop for learning in one system, by one person. Skillgenie is designed to record one’s applications of their self-learning (currently skewed towards actionable skills like golf or chess) and create friendly visualizations, give helpful tips and link to a community, all while seeking to further the user's ability to gather, retain and use any information. 

May 2015 Build - Initial Goal Menu
![](/content/images/2015/Jun/Screen-Shot-2015-06-08-at-9-44-09-PM.jpg)

May 2015 Build - Timeline View
![](/content/images/2015/Jun/Screen-Shot-2015-06-08-at-9-46-10-PM.jpg)

May 2015 Build - Metric View
![](/content/images/2015/Jun/Screen-Shot-2015-06-08-at-9-45-11-PM.jpg)

Dec 2014 Alpha Build
![](/content/images/2015/Jan/Screen-Shot-2015-01-10-at-11-48-44-PM.png)

![](/content/images/2015/Jan/Screen-Shot-2015-01-10-at-11-49-27-PM.png)

An in depth explanation of the multiple application layers does far more justice than the above overview, so please, read on! What follows are sections from various essays written about the uses of & research behind this infant stage of the application.

####Excerpts from Research
######From "Introduction"
Self-learning is a subject that extends into many different disciplines. The most accessible way to enter the arena of altering mental processes is through the promise of “rapid skill acquisition.” Semi-scientific, non-academic writers such as Josh Kaufman and Tim Ferriss are accomplished investigators into this topic, championing simple, multi-step methods to “learn anything”. Bordering on self-help, these authors present steps that inject confidence and heightened sensitivity to information into a reader’s learning process. In the 4 Hour Chef , Ferriss dramatically unveils his rigorously (actually) tested methods for acquiring skills which seem to elude most learners. These authors do much to demystify seemingly intuitive skills, such as cooking, language learning, and musicianship. Although their empirically verified methods actually do promote self-learning, the authors fail to discuss any deeper grounding in a parent discipline, and thus, the steps seem to lack continuity. 

Despite this underlying “feeling”, there are many direct parallels in to Kaufman and Ferriss in the scientific study of metacognition. For example, Kaufman says to “Define your target performance level” as an endpoint for one’s skill acquisition, which is an important piece of data in measuring metacognitive judgements; whether one actually is doing as well as they say. However, in Kaufman’s system there is no mechanism by which to measure actual performance, so there is a very likely risk of repeating an erroneous process. A crucial point about self-learning is be able execute any mental process correctly, and rapid learning systems are unable to enforce this self-correction. There is little doubt whether a person can carry out the steps put forth by Kaufman and Ferriss, however, there is no way besides a total failure of the skill at the end of the process (ie: last place at the golf competition, unable to communicate with Japanese people) to motivate a correction of learning. Even if one competed in successively more difficult golf tournaments, as a “measuring stick” of progress, there would be no criteria by which to alter the learning process if one finds that they have a less than satisfactory grip on the skill. Although the processes detailed by Ferriss and Kaufman are explicit, they are of little use to a person who lacks the knowledge to self-regulate.
    
The Skillgenie app was born from this need, seeking to report individual metacognitive measurements to augment the lack of correction in rapid learning. Data is given by the user in the form of individual posts concerning learning goals/progress/landmarks on a timeline illustrating a skill being learned (Simple & actionable, Ex: “Playing Golf"). Data in/about their posts is aggregated, computed and presented to the user in the form of friendly, readable metrics concerning the learning process. The hope is that the user can use this data to accelerate their learning, by improving upon the process itself and thus being able to interact with the content at a more enjoyable speed, with less failure...

######From "Towards Metacognitive Measurment"

There are three perspectives from which metacognitive measurements have been researched: computational, neurobiological and psychological. Until the late 20th century, the psychological perspective has been responsible for maturing the discipline of metacognition from its roots in the philosophy of mind. Concerning the computational perspective, the analysis of mental structures and processes is becoming increasingly crucial for the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning. The computational “human in the loop” simulation method of assessing aptitude in a specific activity (think flight simulation), is heavily dependent on the analysis of judgements, confidence and memory. The reality of psychophysical reductionism is confirmed in the neurobiological perspective on metacognition, as “our understanding of psychological constructs… have been enriched by the knowledge of their neural underpinnings.” In “Studying Metacognitive Processes at the Single Neuron Level”, Middlebrows et al express a similar sentiment, “neuronal correlates such of functions such as attention, executive control, working memory, decision-making and reward processing, all have been elucidated, to an impressive level of detail, at the single cell and circuit levels.” All of these perspectives serve to play an important role in the development of the Skillgenie metrics, however, we must begin by making clear what we are measuring before we discuss any nuances of implementation.

The key element that makes learners less error prone is a higher level of metacognitive efficiency. Although I will explain this more in depth, a working definition for efficiency is the measure of “objective memory ability” in a person. There are a series of measurements that comprise efficiency, namely: cognitive monitoring, metacognitive sensitivity & bias via “feeling of knowing” (FOK) judgements and metacognitive sensitivity & bias via “judgements of learning” (JOL). We are able to reach the efficiency measure by first assessing one’s executive control of memory, then calculating the disparity between one’s judgements about their knowledge vs. the reality of the situation.

Straddling the line between psychological and neurobiological, we have memory, which Pina Tarricone in “The Taxonomy of Metacognition” says is the foundational, primarily measurable construct of metacognition. A study of metacognition in neuroscience concerns the “monitoring and control of information processing”. Arthur Shimamura in “Toward a Cognitive Neuroscience of Metacognition” gives parallel concepts for executive processes studied in neuroscience, one of which is cognitive monitoring. Monitoring (whose parallel process is called ‘updating’) “refers to the ability to modulate and rearrange activity in working memory.” This measure of executive control is crucial to mitigating errors in comprehension. Consider the following situation: a Skillgenie user watches a video by Tiger Woods on golf, saying that a good swing is dependent upon pivoting the foot exactly 45 degrees, and then overwrites the good information with false information given by his caddy, on the course. Because their working memory is deficient, they will continue to commit this same error...

####Current Stage: Timeline & Metric Views 

In order to implement a self-learning system that facilitates and promotes self-correction, it was necessary to harness the above metacognitive measurements. I chose to develop a “full-stack” Javascript web app named Skillgenie that, in essence, creates a feedback loop for learning in one system. If we take the traditional academic system, in which a student is presented with information, applies the information, then receives feedback on their application; the entire process spans a large amount of time. Skillgenie is designed to record one’s applications of their self-learning, so presentation of the information is a non-issue. However, Skillgenie (in its current state) becomes useful for tracking the progression of applications, from landmark “Goals” and steps to achieve those goals (“Practices”). The last two steps of the traditional educative feedback loop, application and feedback are dynamic in Skillgenie. To receive feedback on general aspects of learning, it becomes as easy as flipping over to the “Metrics” view. For example, Skillgenie is able to calculate cognitive confidence via the user’s practice and goal “difficulty” data to present accessible visualizations and actionable suggestions such as “decreasing (or increasing) the difficulty of goals” Skillgenie is designed to present the connections between applications of learning and especially between projected tasks and actual tasks. In both Ferriss and Kaufman’s accounts of learning a skill, deconstruction is necessary. The “timeline” view of Skillgenie functions like a todo list, where the user can project goals into the future and then track each step to achieving the goal. 
    
For measurement purposes, Skillgenie cements and hides some of the initial data entered about practices and goals, to present the user with data about their own notions of progress versus what is actually taking place. Each practice and goal shares a relationship to one another, either by parent goal or ramping difficulty (deviation of difficulty), so that the user can gain a holistic view of their learning process. In traditional methods of metacognitive measurement, the subject is usually presented with a questionnaire. Especially when asked about their “feeling of knowing”, students are blatantly asked, “how do you think you did on the test?” To avoid this removal from the immersion of self-reflection, Skillgenie tracks and computes confidence based on data given by the user. In other words, it is not blatantly obvious that measurement is taking place.The goal of many measuring efforts in metacognition focus on accuracy apart from the specific level of performance or, “objective memory ability”. These efforts, however fail to give the subject  any concrete or actionable data about themselves. In addition, measurements like meta-d`, while extremely useful, have little to do with any specific context and have no correlate information for the layperson. Skillgenie attempts to make these scientific metrics available and accessible for all learners. 

####The Road Ahead

Thank you for bearing with me through the "wall of text". I am not sure whether writing about Skillgenie makes me more or less confused about the concept, but it certainly informs my progress. I plan to smooth out the stark front end and deepen the metrics with a study of Machine Learning over the next 4 months (completed). Eventually, I would like to make this a usable application, open to the public, but for now, an account system and community linkage are low on my list. Thus, this project has become more of a proof of concept, more about the quality and depth of the application than an effort to push it out the door. 

+ For technology questions, please refer to my research oriented [repository](https://github.com/jacksonsouza/399-mlc).

+ For the source code itself, please go [here](https://github.com/jacksonsouza/skillgenie).

Latest Build: https://damp-depths-5898.herokuapp.com/

If we take the traditional academic system of learning, in which a student is presented with information, applies the information, then receives feedback on their application; the entire process spans a large amount of time. This system requires multiple people, in an often non-ideal environment, with an ever dwindling pool of resources. If we look at learning outside of traditional education, there are many resources that meet specific informational needs. This mirrors K-12 education, where classes only exist on the merit of their content. Despite this, arguably the most important thing one learns in school is not the specifics of dead presidents and algebra, but how to internalize the information.

Skillgenie is a platform that facilitates independent education, completely apart from the specifics of the information. At its core, the app creates a habitual feedback loop for learning in one system, by one person. Skillgenie is designed to record one’s applications of their self-learning (currently skewed towards actionable skills like golf or chess) and create friendly visualizations, give helpful tips and link to a community, all while seeking to further the user's ability to gather, retain and use any information.

May 2015 Build - Initial Goal Menu

May 2015 Build - Timeline View

May 2015 Build - Metric View

Dec 2014 Alpha Build

An in depth explanation of the multiple application layers does far more justice than the above overview, so please, read on! What follows are sections from various essays written about the uses of & research behind this infant stage of the application.

posts.title: Skillgenie 10
posts.markdown:
For Weeks 2 & 3 of semester,
concerning catagories: **Linear *Regression* &  Optimization**,
specifically the algorithm: **Batch Gradient Descent.**

*Simple, easy to use & widely applicable*

___
**Order of Learning**:

+ Watched Ng Lecture, read "Optimization" section in "Programming Collective Intelligence", reviewed Ng notes.
+ Watched few clarification videos & read relevant introductory blog posts, chapters
+ Dissected parts of algorithms & learned associated ML concepts. Helpful to look at the linear algebra scope.
+ Compiled list of examples
+ Played with examples
+ Examined applications

**Terms**:

+ Optimization
+ Linear Regression
+ (Batch) Gradient Descent: Minimization (the GD part) of a function (the cost function). Useful for one variable. This is the learning algorithm. In the context of linear regression, we "run gradient descent (the process which marches the program forward) on the cost function" to evaluate how good the hypothesis is. 
	+ Hypothesis: Starting function, what is revised by learning algorithm (*the line*).
	+ Gradient: The compass, keeps the algorithm generating in the correct direction.
	+ Theta: The weights (values) which make the resulting function useful. "The whole purpose of writing the ML algorithm is to come-up with values of theta that will make our hypothesis function fit the training set well." You want theta to converge with the minimum value in the data set, this is the point of gradient *descent*.
    + Cost/Loss/Error: How we evaluate the goodness of the line in relation to the data. We normally calculate this cost by ordinary least squares method. This is specific to linear regression.
    + Alpha/Learning Rate: How large are the steps the function takes? Computational power vs. accuracy (risk of overshooting the min.)

**Explanations**:

Wikipedia...
http://spin.atomicobject.com/2014/06/24/gradient-descent-linear-regression/
http://aimotion.blogspot.com/2011/10/machine-learning-with-python-linear.html

**Examples**:

[1](http://stackoverflow.com/a/17796231)
[2](http://www.bogotobogo.com/python/python_numpy_batch_gradient_descent_algorithm.php)

**Applications**:
The context that Andrew Ng presented this gradient descent in was to estimate housing prices. Given a small batch (*all* prices would need mini-batch processing, or stochastic descent) of housing prices, could we create a linear function (essentially draw the *perfect* line through a set of points) so that given the X (sqaure footage) we can accurately estimate a Y (price).

I took an example off of stack overflow and tried to mimic the article by showing the plots via pandas.
___
####Tools
Python
Enthought Canopy
ipython
scikit-learn

+ pandas
+ matplotlib
+ numpy
+ scipy
___

####Regarding Trello Goals
 - Did not impliment **require.js**, instead opting for whatever Krol had implimented with Browserify. I understand dependancy management with bower and npm, however the purpose of async loading escapes me. I will have to ask someone to explain this to me. In the mean time, I will leave any loading out until encounter an issue.
 	+ Here ([1](http://blog.startifact.com/posts/overwhelmed-by-javascript-dependencies.html), [2](http://blog.startifact.com/posts/js-dependency-tools-redux.html)) are some posts concerning dependancy confusion.
    + My question is: why do we need to load front-end dependancies in the same way that require() does for node? What advantages does this bring? Why? I understand how bower & npm differ from this, as they are not *loaders*.
    + As far as RequireJS modularizing the code, isn't this aspect redundant as far as Backbone.Marionette goes. Do we need further modularization with the framework and strict adherence to MVC?

posts.title: Skillgenie - Spring 2015 [Meta]
posts.markdown:
For Spring 2015 Semester, course of study in Data Science.

___
#Initial Aims

**Last semester I...**

Using the n-back & JOL efficiency measures, I was able to abstract whether the user was "overconfident" and should lower the difficulty of their tasks or the opposite. This relied upon self reporting, which is subject to human error. Can I use machine learning to make more of, and more accurate abstractions from psychologically measured data about one's executive control or learning aptitude.

**So now I will...**

Furthering the proof of concept with Machine Learning in Python. Smooth the interface (think Minimum Viable Product w/o accounts, etc.) then, use machine learning to inform the metacognition. Harnessing the data set to make actionable, useful, unique suggestions.

Specifically, deepen the (one or two) metrics & use machine learning to create helpful abstractions from the data store, across time or in specific instances.


Pursuing high proficiency in Python & associated machine learning libraries (numpy, pandas, scipy, matplotlib, *all often in scikit-learn*), existing JS stack & visualization (D3.js via http://mpld3.github.io/).


Aiming for high proficiency in the front end [interest in interaction design, data visulaization & associated fields]. Pursuing competency in Machine Learning & associated "AI"-like fields.
___
#Project Goals
Analysis of task (procedural) knowledge to inform the person (declaritive) knowledge. This process, over time, constructs strategic (situational) knowledge.

1. Here is what you struggle with
2. I struggle with this
3. I should avoid this


All centered around guiding the user, self-correction.

Predictive metrics (3) - "A prediction of future learning using a synthesis of project-specifical and *all* given data" Ex: "You are headed this way, you have a history of heading this way, so I suggest this result." Say, difficulty of a goal should be the stopping point, min value, NOT a part of the data set itself. The ML is for prediction, let it do its job! As a result of the prediction, we suggest a course of action. The appropriate course of action is predicted by the algorithm. Ask, is the problem a regression problem or classification problem?

- *Approach*: Refine **difficulty** metric, when the goal/practice distinction is eliminated (no input of future events, functions more truely like a tracker). The user's difficulty should be tracked, projected & compared with projected difficulty. Should result in a suggested tailoring of the user's difficulty of future posts. "Slow down cowboy, learn the basics" or "Accelarate your learning, jump ahead". How hard did you feel the content was?

- *Comprehension*: **Judgements of learning** metric. Multivarible prediction assesing the comprehension of content. "Go back and repeat step 27", for identifying breaking points or large gaps in learning. How new or unrelated did the content feel?

- *Execution*: "When you attempted to apply this material, did the research content improve your skill?" Capitalizing on the application & research distinction. Not fleshed out.




Purely synthetic metrics - "A synthesis of past information"

- Post count
- Overall difficulty, etc..

___
#Topics of Study

#####Python
ML libraries
Pythonic programming

#####Data Science
"Advice for applying machine learning"
Machine learning (ML)
Presenting analytical data (visualization, etc...)

###ML Algorithms
Goal is to learn the basic types of supervised learning problems (classification, regression & clustering) and some algorithms that allow me to use them.
#####Regression

+ Linear regression (Least Squares, GD)
+ Logistic regression (SGD)

#####*Clustering

+ k-means

#####*Bayesian Classifier (Naive)

#####*Descision Trees


#####Kernel - Support-Vector Machines (SVM)

___
#Resources

[A Tour of Machine Learning Algorithms](http://machinelearningmastery.com/a-tour-of-machine-learning-algorithms/)

[Deep Learning Reading List](http://jmozah.github.io/links/)

**[Programming Collective Intelligence: Building Smart Web 2.0 Applications](http://www.amazon.com/Doing-Data-Science-Straight-Frontline/dp/1449358659/ref=pd_bxgy_b_text_z)** - Great for introduction or initial clarification

[Doing Data Science: Straight Talk from the Frontline](http://www.amazon.com/Doing-Data-Science-Straight-Frontline/dp/1449358659/ref=pd_bxgy_b_text_z) - Great for in depth clarification

[Python for Data Analysis](http://www.amazon.com/Python-Data-Analysis-Wrangling-IPython/dp/1449319793/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1420768337&sr=1-2&keywords=python+machine+learning) - Python tool based

[University of Washington - Machine Learning](https://class.coursera.org/machlearning-001/lecture)

**[Andrew Ng's Stanford ML Intro Course](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UzxYlbK2c7E&list=PLA89DCFA6ADACE599)** - Introduction to all concepts, guiding light in the AI darkness

+ [Andrew Ng's Stanford ML Resources]( Coursehttp://cs229.stanford.edu/materials.html)

+ [Andrew Ng's Coursera Videos]( https://class.coursera.org/ml-003/lecture)

**[Andrew Ihler's ML Intro Course](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qPhMX0vb6D8&list=PLaXDtXvwY-oDvedS3f4HW0b4KxqpJ_imw)** - Great for clarification

[mathematicalmonk's ML Channel](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLD0F06AA0D2E8FFBA)

**[Trello - Skillgenie Development Task/Issue List](https://trello.com/b/lRuBFuiv/skillgenie-development)**
