Specifically, deepen the (one or two) metrics & use machine learning to create helpful abstractions from the data store, across time or in specific instances.

Pursuing high proficiency in Python & associated machine learning libraries (numpy, pandas, scipy, matplotlib, all often in scikit-learn), existing JS stack & visualization (D3.js via http://mpld3.github.io/).

Aiming for high proficiency in the front end [interest in interaction design, data visulaization & associated fields]. Pursuing competency in Machine Learning & associated "AI"-like fields.

Project Goals

Analysis of task (procedural) knowledge to inform the person (declaritive) knowledge. This process, over time, constructs strategic (situational) knowledge.

  1. Here is what you struggle with
  2. I struggle with this
  3. I should avoid this

All centered around guiding the user, self-correction.

Predictive metrics (3) - "A prediction of future learning using a synthesis of project-specifical and all given data" Ex: "You are headed this way, you have a history of heading this way, so I suggest this result." Say, difficulty of a goal should be the stopping point, min value, NOT a part of the data set itself. The ML is for prediction, let it do its job! As a result of the prediction, we suggest a course of action. The appropriate course of action is predicted by the algorithm. Ask, is the problem a regression problem or classification problem?

  • Approach: Refine difficulty metric, when the goal/practice distinction is eliminated (no input of future events, functions more truely like a tracker). The user's difficulty should be tracked, projected & compared with projected difficulty. Should result in a suggested tailoring of the user's difficulty of future posts. "Slow down cowboy, learn the basics" or "Accelarate your learning, jump ahead". How hard did you feel the content was?

  • Comprehension: Judgements of learning metric. Multivarible prediction assesing the comprehension of content. "Go back and repeat step 27", for identifying breaking points or large gaps in learning. How new or unrelated did the content feel?

  • Execution: "When you attempted to apply this material, did the research content improve your skill?" Capitalizing on the application & research distinction. Not fleshed out.

Purely synthetic metrics - "A synthesis of past information"

  • Post count
  • Overall difficulty, etc..

Topics of Study

Python

ML libraries
Pythonic programming

Data Science

"Advice for applying machine learning"
Machine learning (ML)
Presenting analytical data (visualization, etc...)

ML Algorithms

Goal is to learn the basic types of supervised learning problems (classification, regression & clustering) and some algorithms that allow me to use them.

Regression
  • Linear regression (Least Squares, GD)
  • Logistic regression (SGD)
*Clustering
  • k-means
*Bayesian Classifier (Naive)
*Descision Trees
Kernel - Support-Vector Machines (SVM)

Resources

A Tour of Machine Learning Algorithms

Deep Learning Reading List

Programming Collective Intelligence: Building Smart Web 2.0 Applications - Great for introduction or initial clarification

Doing Data Science: Straight Talk from the Frontline - Great for in depth clarification

Python for Data Analysis - Python tool based

University of Washington - Machine Learning

Andrew Ng's Stanford ML Intro Course - Introduction to all concepts, guiding light in the AI darkness

  • Andrew Ng's Stanford ML Resources

  • Andrew Ng's Coursera Videos

Andrew Ihler's ML Intro Course - Great for clarification

mathematicalmonk's ML Channel

Trello - Skillgenie Development Task/Issue List

posts.title: Skillgenie 11
posts.markdown:
Week 4, notes on trello clear.
Basically restructuring the web app, getting directory structure, buildability, dependancy management and templating all straight.

+ Get Sulc's requirejs app fully communicating with server & database
+ Restructure directories
	+ Server & misc
    + Client app (keep attempting to compile Require. `node r.js -o assets/js/build.js)
+ Connect app to database, detatch from localstorage
+ Redo templating in handlebars
	+ Restructure directories
+ Insert metric & timeline code (insert the Skillgenie, views, data massage, etc...)
+ Refactor code
+ Get buildable (w/ Bower & NPM), like BENM
+ Host app (Heroku?)

###Notes on Heroku
Needed "Procfile", no extension
No node_modules folder, let npm build the app!
at: https://damp-depths-5898.herokuapp.com/#timeline

Now that you have a Heroku account and the Toolbelt installed, you’re ready to create an app under your account, prepare the app, and push your code live. Along the way you’ll install a few Add-ons as well.

Note: All of the following commands should be executed from the root of the project directory.

$ heroku login
After logging in, you may be prompted to add SSH keys. Follow the directions as you go.

Next create a file named ‘Procfile’ and put the following single line of code in it:

1
web: node server.js
Create an app under your Heroku account:

$ heroku create

`Next we need to install the first add-on for the app, MongoHQ. MongoHQ is another cloud based hosting service specifically for MongoDB that works extremely well with Heroku. Like Heroku, MongoHQ has a sandbox level service that is absolutely free!`

$ heroku addons:add mongohq
Note: In order to actually use add-ons, you will need to be sure your account has complete billing information. This is only because most services are scalable and have limited terms. Should you exceed those terms then billing would kick in.

```
Next go to the Heroku website and access your dashboard/Apps. Click on the app that was just created, and then click on the MongoHQ Add-on. Go into the Collections and add a collection for your app (i.e. “contacts”). Then go into Admin and select the Users tab. Create a new user to access the database (give it any username/password you want). Switch back to the Overview tab and copy the Mongo URI.

Edit server.js and the line that connects to the mongodb server will need to be changed to the Mongo URI that was just copied. Change the <user> and <password> to the MongoHQ user that you just created.
```

Now we can push our code up to Heroku:

Note: Before you push your code to Heroku, because it uses Git to do so, you want to make sure that any changes you’ve made up to this point have been staged and committed (i.e. that change you just made to server.js for your MongoHQ connection URI). The easiest way to do that is with the following commands:
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "Updates for Heroku"
$ git push heroku master
Now that the app is setup, add-ons installed, and code pushed up we need Heroku to actually launch our server. To do this Heroku uses something called a dyno which will read the Procfile and execute its command:

$ heroku ps:scale web=1
Finally, launch your new Heorku app in a browser:

$ heroku open

###Notes on RequireJS
Basically, we need it, it is part of the stack, and it is a best practice.

Here is a post on Almond.js and why we are using it on top of Require: http://www.justinmccandless.com/blog/Building+a+Requirejs+Project+to+a+Single,+Reusable+File

Always use Ctrl + C when terminating an instance of Grunt.

###Notes on Web App Directory Structure.

From http://www.terlici.com/2014/08/25/best-practices-express-structure.html:
```
project/
  controllers/
    comments.js
    index.js
    users.js
  helpers/
    dates.js
  middlewares/
    auth.js
    users.js
  models/
    comment.js
    user.js
  public/
    libs/
    css/
    img/
  views/
    comments/
      comment.jade
    users/
    index.jade
  tests/
    controllers/
    models/
      comment.js
    middlewares/
    integration/
    ui/
  .gitignore
  app.js
  package.json
```

Lineman.js:
```
.
├── app
│   ├── js                  # <-- JS & CoffeeScript
│   ├── img                 # <-- images (are merged into the 'img' folder inside of generated & dist)
│   ├── static              # <-- any other static files that need to be placed in a path relative to `/`
│   └── pages               # <-- static HTML pages (underscore and handlebars templates are supported)
│       └── index.us        # <-- a template used to produce the application's index.html
│   └── templates           # <-- client-side templates
│       ├── other.us        # <-- other templates will be compiled to a window.JST object
│       └── thing.hb        # <-- underscore & handlebars are both already set up
│       └── _partial.hb     # <-- a handlebars partial, usable from within other handlebars templates
├── config
│   ├── application.js      # <-- Override application configuration
│   ├── files.js            # <-- Override named file patterns
│   ├── server.js           # <-- Define custom server-side endpoints to aid in development
│   └── spec.json           # <-- Override spec run configurations
├── dist                    # <-- Generated, production-ready app assets
├── generated               # <-- Generated, pre-production app assets
├── grunt.js                # <-- gruntfile defines app's task config
├── package.json            # <-- Project's package.json
├── tasks                   # <-- Custom grunt tasks can be defined here
├── spec
│   ├── helpers             # <-- Spec helpers (loaded before other specs)
│   └── some-spec.coffee    # <-- All the Jasmine specs you can write (JS or Coffee)
└── vendor                  # <-- 3rd-party assets will be prepended or merged into the application
    ├── js                  # <-- 3rd-party Javascript
    │   └── underscore.js   # <-- Underscore, because underscore is fantastic.
    ├── img                 # <-- 3rd-party images (are merged into the 'img' folder inside of generated & dist)
    ├── css                 # <-- 3rd-party CSS
    └── static              # <-- any 3rd-party static files that need to be placed in a path relative to `/`
```

From [What is your folder-structure preference for a large-scale Node.js project?](https://gist.github.com/lancejpollard/1398757) a lá Rails:

```
|-- app
|   |-- controllers
|   |   |-- admin
|   |   |   |-- postsController.js
|   |   |   `-- usersController.js
|   |   |-- postsController.js
|   |   |-- sessionsController.js
|   |   `-- usersController.js
|   |-- models
|   |   |-- post.js
|   |   `-- user.js
|   |-- views
|   |   |-- admin
|   |   |   `-- posts
|   |   |       |-- edit.jade
|   |   |       |-- index.jade
|   |   |       |-- new.jade
|   |   |-- layouts
|   |   |   `-- application.jade
|   |   `-- posts
|   |       |-- index.jade
|   |       `-- show.jade
|   `-- helpers
|       |-- admin
|       |   |-- postsHelper.js
|       |   `-- tagsHelper.js
|       `-- postsHelper.js
`-- config
|    |-- application.js
|    |-- locale
|        `-- en.js
|    |-- routes.js
`-- lib
`-- spec
|    |-- helper.js
|    |-- models
|    |   |-- postSpec.js
|    |   |-- userSpec.js
|    `-- acceptance
|        |-- loginSpec.js
|        |-- signupSpec.js
|        `-- postsSpec.js
`-- vendor
|    |-- javascripts
|    |   |-- jquery.js
|    |   |-- underscore.js
|    `-- stylesheets
|        `-- prettyPhoto.css
```

From [Symphony](http://symfony.com/legacy/doc/book/1_0/en/02-Exploring-Symfony-s-Code#chapter_02_sub_file_tree_structure)

```
apps/
  frontend/
  backend/
batch/
cache/
config/
data/
  sql/
doc/
lib/
  model/
log/
plugins/
test/
  unit/
  functional/
web/
  css/
  images/
  js/
  uploads/
```

posts.title: Interview Preparation
posts.markdown:
Figured I needed some good ol' interview practice. This post is mainly for code based questions, however, theory/terms/subject based questions are good too. I will leave company based questions for a case by case basis.

All done in JS unless otherwise specified.

Code can be found at https://github.com/jacksonsouza/polyglot.

Run in command-line with `node hello.js`

**2/4 - Fizz Buzz**: Write a program that prints the numbers from 1 to 100. But for multiples of three print “Fizz” instead of the number and for the multiples of five print “Buzz”. For numbers which are multiples of both three and five print “FizzBuzz”

+ Terniary Expressions



**2/6 - Fizz Buzz in Ruby**:

+ Run with `ruby fizzbuzz.rb`
+ Done with the assistance of Learn X (Ruby) in Y minutes.


**2/6 - Anagrams in JS**:

Check whether strings are anagrams of eachother. Anagrams are words with same characters in different order. `star == tsar` `heelo != hello`.

**2/9 - Naive Primality Test (isPrime)**:

The simplest primality test is *trial division*: Given an input number n, check whether any integer m from 2 to n − 1 evenly divides n (the division leaves no remainder). If n is divisible by any m then n is composite, otherwise it is prime.

[List of 100 primes](http://primes.utm.edu/lists/small/1000.txt)


**2/10 - Array Pair Sum**:

Given an integer array, output all distinct and non-zero pairs that sum up to a specific value k.

**2/11 - Email Duplicate Removal for ChefSteps**:

In your favorite language, write a working function that removes all duplicates from an unsorted list of email addresses while leaving the remaining list in the original order.  It should be able to handle say, 100,000 email addresses containing 50% randomly placed duplicates in well under 1 second on a typical modern laptop. How would your implementation be different if it needed to handle millions of records? Billions?

**2/12 - Find Missing Element**

There is an array of non-negative integers. A second array is formed by shuffling the elements of the first array and deleting a random element. Given these two arrays, find which element is missing in the second array.

**2/16 & 2/17 - Linked Lists**

+ Research + understanding
+ Class + method implimentation in JS
+ Given a linked list of integers and an integer value, delete every node of the linkedlist containing that value.
+ Write code to remove duplicates from an unsorted linked list.
+ Implement an algorithm to find the nth to last element of a singly linked list. Impliment removal and addition at this certain location.


**2/18 - Hash Tables**

[CS 50 - Hash Tables](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h2d9b_nEzoA)

[PaulProgramming - Hash Tables](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MfhjkfocRR0)

Hash table vs lookup table/dictionary (object literal): In JS, it is an abuse of the terminology to say that an JSON object literal like:
```
literal = {
	key: value
}
```
accessable by `literal["key"]` is a hash table. Hash tables are built upon an array where the index of the desired pair is known by feeding the desired key into the hash function. They are both types of associative arrays, and JS uses object literals as associative arrays. 

Really, you wouldn't use a hash table over a plain object literal unless you needed the actual hashing functionality (for passwords or other sensitive info).

**2/18 - isSubstring & Rotation**

Assume you have a method isSubstring which checks if one word is a substring of another Given two strings, s1 and s2, write code to check if s2 is a rotation of s1 using only one call to isSubstring (i e , “waterbottle” is a rotation of “erbottlewat”)

**2/19 - Binary Trees**

[BT vs. BST](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6380231/difference-between-binary-tree-and-binary-search-tree)

[Trees - CS50](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mFptHjTT3l8)

Binary Tree: At most, two children

+ Class + methods implimentation in JS
+ Given a sorted (increasing order) array, write an algorithm to create a binary tree with minimal height.

**2/20 - Review**

How we solve problems:

+ Identify the pattern. If the problem is isPrime(), what are the conditions of a prime number.

+ Psuedocode
+ Durrr...

Review involves looking over (all) & whiteboarding (one or two) finished solutions, and reviewing common solutions on thatJSDude, Arden, StackOverflow.

**2/21 - Quick Sort + Review**

[CS50, Quicksort](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aQiWF4E8flQ)

[Better Explanation by Computerphile](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XE4VP_8Y0BU)

[Recursive Implimentation of Quicksort](http://antjanus.com/blog/web-development-tutorials/understanding-quicksort-js-native-implementation/)

**2/22 - Stacks & ArrayLists + Review**

Stacks: data only accessable from the top, via pop() and added by push(). Last in, first out. Still harnesses data via nodes, however only allows access from the top. Good for order, not for much else.

ArrayList: dynamically resizing array. JS arrays already have this functionality. Should allocate double the size of the array when all availible memory has been taken up.

**2/23 - Major Review**

[Explanation of Recursive Fibonacci](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg-ddPbzcKM)

**2/25 - BSTs and Breadth First Traversal**

Using queues is the most painless way to do BFT. Queues in javascript operate where enqueue is push() and dequeue is shift().

[Refer to "Method 2"](http://www.geeksforgeeks.org/level-order-tree-traversal/)

[Implimentation of BST in JS](http://www.geeksforgeeks.org/level-order-tree-traversal/)


**3/3, 3/5 - Interviews with Formidable Labs & Bloomz**

Formidable: Modification of [Project Euler - 81](https://projecteuler.net/problem=81), given a three-dimensional "triangular" array, find the path from top to bottom that gives least sum.

**3/11 - Getting Back in the Game: Codewars - 8 Rooks (7 Kyu)**

Write a function that, given a positive integer `n` (the `n x n` size of a chess board), returns the number of different combinations in which the rooks can be arranged.

Rooks can only move down the board, vertically or horizontally. `x` denotes the position of the rook, while a `0` indicates an open space. Contrary to actual chess, you begin with a rook in each row. You can never have a more than one rook in a row or column (rooks may *only* be adjacent or not touching).

Example:
towerCombination(2) returns 2! solutions, because only the following possibilities can be achieved.
```
| 0 x |
| x 0 |

| x 0 |
| 0 x |
```

**3/23 to 3/30 - Week of Pain: Formidable Labs Preparation**

Items are listed in order of importance.
(Split time: Immediate or Past Review / New Information / Application)

+ Web Application Development: Node.js
	+ [Introduction to Node.js](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pU9Q6oiQNd0)
	+ [Introduction to Web Application Development with Express.js](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FqMIyTH9wSg)
    + [Formidable Labs: Learn Node](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/10yqGXoBy4V88f1iL02ORgGx3YX26jNPVZjanq6rU_Nw/edit#slide=id.g1057f7cfb_0213)
    + [Mixu's Node Book](http://book.mixu.net/node/index.html)
    + Database Fundimentals with MongoDB
    + REST
    
**Relevant concepts**: Asynchronous vs synchronous execution, Node's async control flow.



    
+ Data Structures & Algorithms Review
	+ Programming Languages: Facets of JS
    + Faux-OO in Javascript
	+ String & Array Manipulation
	+ Common Mathematics Problems (Fib, isPrime)
    + Common Design Patterns & Terminology (ex: Singleton Design, OO)
    
Refer to thatJSdude & other problem resources. Hard problems should incorparate data structures, but not so much large conceptual problems like Codewars. Need to cover Big O & Recursion thouroughly, other than that review all algorithms and data structures. Refer to Javascript: The Good Parts.

As far as data structures, know them all, prime yourself on graphs & heaps with traveling salesman. Algorithms need to know one tree search (BFS), one sort (Quicksort).

posts.html:
Figured I needed some good ol' interview practice. This post is mainly for code based questions, however, theory/terms/subject based questions are good too. I will leave company based questions for a case by case basis.

All done in JS unless otherwise specified.

Code can be found at https://github.com/jacksonsouza/polyglot.

Run in command-line with node hello.js

2/4 - Fizz Buzz: Write a program that prints the numbers from 1 to 100. But for multiples of three print “Fizz” instead of the number and for the multiples of five print “Buzz”. For numbers which are multiples of both three and five print “FizzBuzz”

  • Terniary Expressions

2/6 - Fizz Buzz in Ruby:

  • Run with ruby fizzbuzz.rb
  • Done with the assistance of Learn X (Ruby) in Y minutes.

2/6 - Anagrams in JS:

Check whether strings are anagrams of eachother. Anagrams are words with same characters in different order. star == tsar heelo != hello.

2/9 - Naive Primality Test (isPrime):

The simplest primality test is trial division: Given an input number n, check whether any integer m from 2 to n − 1 evenly divides n (the division leaves no remainder). If n is divisible by any m then n is composite, otherwise it is prime.

List of 100 primes

2/10 - Array Pair Sum:

Given an integer array, output all distinct and non-zero pairs that sum up to a specific value k.

2/11 - Email Duplicate Removal for ChefSteps:

In your favorite language, write a working function that removes all duplicates from an unsorted list of email addresses while leaving the remaining list in the original order. It should be able to handle say, 100,000 email addresses containing 50% randomly placed duplicates in well under 1 second on a typical modern laptop. How would your implementation be different if it needed to handle millions of records? Billions?

2/12 - Find Missing Element

There is an array of non-negative integers. A second array is formed by shuffling the elements of the first array and deleting a random element. Given these two arrays, find which element is missing in the second array.

2/16 & 2/17 - Linked Lists

  • Research + understanding
  • Class + method implimentation in JS
  • Given a linked list of integers and an integer value, delete every node of the linkedlist containing that value.
  • Write code to remove duplicates from an unsorted linked list.
  • Implement an algorithm to find the nth to last element of a singly linked list. Impliment removal and addition at this certain location.

2/18 - Hash Tables

CS 50 - Hash Tables

PaulProgramming - Hash Tables

Hash table vs lookup table/dictionary (object literal): In JS, it is an abuse of the terminology to say that an JSON object literal like: 

literal = {  
    key: value
}

accessable by literal["key"] is a hash table. Hash tables are built upon an array where the index of the desired pair is known by feeding the desired key into the hash function. They are both types of associative arrays, and JS uses object literals as associative arrays.

Really, you wouldn't use a hash table over a plain object literal unless you needed the actual hashing functionality (for passwords or other sensitive info).

2/18 - isSubstring & Rotation

Assume you have a method isSubstring which checks if one word is a substring of another Given two strings, s1 and s2, write code to check if s2 is a rotation of s1 using only one call to isSubstring (i e , “waterbottle” is a rotation of “erbottlewat”)

2/19 - Binary Trees

BT vs. BST

Trees - CS50

Binary Tree: At most, two children

  • Class + methods implimentation in JS
  • Given a sorted (increasing order) array, write an algorithm to create a binary tree with minimal height.

2/20 - Review

How we solve problems:

  • Identify the pattern. If the problem is isPrime(), what are the conditions of a prime number.

  • Psuedocode

  • Durrr...

Review involves looking over (all) & whiteboarding (one or two) finished solutions, and reviewing common solutions on thatJSDude, Arden, StackOverflow.

2/21 - Quick Sort + Review

CS50, Quicksort

Better Explanation by Computerphile

Recursive Implimentation of Quicksort

2/22 - Stacks & ArrayLists + Review

Stacks: data only accessable from the top, via pop() and added by push(). Last in, first out. Still harnesses data via nodes, however only allows access from the top. Good for order, not for much else.

ArrayList: dynamically resizing array. JS arrays already have this functionality. Should allocate double the size of the array when all availible memory has been taken up.

2/23 - Major Review

Explanation of Recursive Fibonacci

2/25 - BSTs and Breadth First Traversal

Using queues is the most painless way to do BFT. Queues in javascript operate where enqueue is push() and dequeue is shift().

Refer to "Method 2"

Implimentation of BST in JS

3/3, 3/5 - Interviews with Formidable Labs & Bloomz

Formidable: Modification of Project Euler - 81, given a three-dimensional "triangular" array, find the path from top to bottom that gives least sum.

3/11 - Getting Back in the Game: Codewars - 8 Rooks (7 Kyu)

Write a function that, given a positive integer n (the n x n size of a chess board), returns the number of different combinations in which the rooks can be arranged.

Rooks can only move down the board, vertically or horizontally. x denotes the position of the rook, while a 0 indicates an open space. Contrary to actual chess, you begin with a rook in each row. You can never have a more than one rook in a row or column (rooks may only be adjacent or not touching).

Example:
towerCombination(2) returns 2! solutions, because only the following possibilities can be achieved. 

| 0 x |
| x 0 |

| x 0 |
| 0 x |

posts.title: Skillgenie 12
posts.html:
Weeks 5 & 6

Decided to split up each week with two days of Trello, two days of ML learning.

ML will be focused on Logistic Regression, following the same learning process as Weeks 2 & 3.

Notes on Logistic Regression

  • Read corresponding section in "Doing Data Science"
  • Looked for clarificatory info on stackexchage, "for what is this used? when is it used? how is it different from what I have already learned?"
  • Selected an algorithm...
  • Looked at examples in Python
    • http://aimotion.blogspot.com/2011/11/machine-learning-with-python-logistic.html
    • http://www.dataschool.io/logistic-regression-in-python-using-scikit-learn/

Regression involves estimating or predicting a response. Classification is identifying group membership. Regression: the output variable takes continuous values. Classification: the output variable takes class labels.

This is nessecarily the difference between LogR & LinR, that LogR is regressing for "the probability of a catagorical outcome, one outcome between two states" while Lin R is regressing to match a specific, continuously fluctuating X to Y "to establish a relationship between a dependant & independant variables".

Notes on Difficulty Metric

"Skillgenie will learn along with you!" Attempting to bring a better insight to metacognitive measure with machine learning.

Proposed difficulty data will be collected across goals, and will not involve expected difficulty. Data will be aggregated as a training set, and processed by the ML algorithm. The gradient descent algorithm will predict the optimum difficulty for a new, proposed task based on Y = difficulty & X = constant, hidden measure of learning (based on time left, or current date,time in the projects). On X: if you are this far along in your goal, time wise or with the number of tasks completed, etc.. how difficult should your task be based on the other goals you have completed and their timelines.

compile almond with node r.js -o client/build.js

For Trello:

  • Connect app to database, detatch from localstorage
  • Insert metric & timeline code (insert the Skillgenie, views, data massage, etc...)
    • Assess and fix all functionality
    • Redo all templating in handlebars
  • Get buildable (w/ Bower & NPM), like BENM
  • Deploy to Heroku (follow instructions for BENM) & Github

Notes on Handlebars

This is the strategy for using compiled at runtime templates. Not precompiled, which would be less expensive for loading.

Helpful resource: http://www.slideshare.net/iivanoo/requirejs-handlebars

Define in Require Main 

paths: {  
          jquery: 'libs/jquery/jquery-min',
          underscore: 'libs/underscore/underscore-min',
          backbone: 'libs/backbone/backbone-optamd3-min',
          handlebars: 'libs/handlebars/handlebars',
          text: 'libs/require/text'
      }


requirejs.config({  
    shim: {
        'handlebars': {
            exports: 'Handlebars'
        }
    }
});

define(["marionette", "handlebars", "text!templates/about/message.handlebars"], function(Marionette, Handlebars, message){  
  return {
    Message: Marionette.ItemView.extend({
      template: Handlebars.compile(message)
    })
  };
});

posts.title: Skillgenie 13
posts.markdown:
###Weeks 12 & 13

On the near completion of Metric 1, heading into the visualization and integration aspect, I have a few thoughts on the data set and chosen linear regression model.

I could have gone one of two ways with my application of machine learning: towards the plug-n-play of scikitlearn and choose a better algorithms to fit the dataset or to learn about the computation taking place and instead bank on my chosen set of algorithms being *made* to work.

Naturally, I chose the second option, as I feel like it is more beneficial to me at this stage to use only what I have made an effort to learn, not a) trying to learn more and neglect my application or b) give in to the plug-n-play, which should only be reserved for learning anyway. Numpy and matplotlib have been my chosen tools for this.

The algorithms I have chosen leave much to be desired, but I feel that if I groom my dataset and not impose too much complexity  on the simple algorithms, I can achive my goals to move this into a demo stage.

In regards to the iterative process of adjusting the problem statement, data and algorithm:
![](/content/images/2015/Apr/Screen-Shot-2015-04-06-at-7-49-51-PM.png)
Here is the current progrssion of the data, given the random sampling the sucesses in regard to time spent and difficulty are not clustered. Presumably, the user would have a clear clustering, like the scond fram in the image below. The algorithm does the best it can with the purely random sampling on a low amount (100) of iterations.


![](/content/images/2015/Apr/IMG_2819.jpg)

For my next metric, im not dead set on an algorithm yet:
http://scikit-learn.org/stable/user_guide.html
http://machinelearningmastery.com/a-tour-of-machine-learning-algorithms/

posts.title: Post-Grad Developments
posts.markdown:
This post begins my journey beyond traditional academic education and into an arena of uncertainty and endless possibilities.

####What I would like to continue doing:

+ Writing long and short philosophically motivated works of analytical & creative writing.
+ Woodworking, music and other "hands on" creative work. I would like to jump back into playing live music or writing scores for small films or games.
+ Small and large open-source works in code. Moving away from web development as my main mode of programming with a trajectory towards machine learning, data science and AI.
+ Teaching & other methods of "reaching out": blog posts, conferences, publishing, tutoring.
+ Mastering finances, investing, and otherwise prudently managing earned passive or creatively attained income.
+ Partaking in learning and application in all of the above subjects.

The first project that I am really interested in taking up is a low maitinence source of income. No new technologies, just full stack JS and python.

In the style of richblockspoorblocks, I would like to create a small, open facing web application that presents otherwise inaccessable or fragmentary data from a large, data rich service (etsy, ebay, curse gaming, wikipedia [via their respective APIs]) in a collected, helpful, visual and easy-to-access interface. I could even use machine learning to add future value in drawing abstractions about the data, furthering the ease of access.

My thoughts on this were to first to choose an mother service, and then a niche within that service (ebay - car salesmen). Then, via the mother service's API, I can design an interface around specific requests for data/knowledge, pitfalls, whatever, that this group might have.

The user is forced to make a very simple account to use, so that usage can be tracked and the paywall can be enforced. The paywall comes in after a certain amount of usage, or for tiers of access to information. Basically, valuable information (lets say to "increase sales") will be withheld for money.

Essentially, this is a freemium utility geared towards a specific group (pet toy makers) for a data-rich mother service (etsy).

For etsy, a few examples would be:

+ Telling a user something that they didn't know about their sales. Tracking the arc of their sales and providing input about what sold best, what to sell again, what is in demand, etc.

+ Providing a query service about products, showing the demand, supply, avg. price. Basically a WoW Auction House helper for Etsy.


**Another idea would be to offer services for academic websites.**

Revision:
It seems as though large companies are more reluctant to let you monatize off of their API. But there are many good APIs for information I can hold behind a paywall. 

In this thought, there are scholarly APIs or even services like Kimono Labs where you can windowshop little thought of APIs. Picking an interesting but useful API or group of them is key here, as this dictates the foundation of the product.

posts.title: Writing
posts.markdown:
Just wanted to jot a few things down about my essay writing process. I'm sitting here writing a Hegel paper.

+ Pick a topic, outline the contours of the assignment/goals.
+ Narrow the topic, try to formulate a vague position
+ Make a general outline of the work, with large section headings split by length. This and the above points are all done on looseleaf paper.
+ Read about the topic & various positions, if you can't seem to write, read more - notate the text, freewrite vague thoughts. This goes for any time that writer's block occurs.
+ Write a shitty introduction, write a shitty thesis.
+ Leave the shitty intro, begin writing the body occording to the large sections in the outline, split these sections up into sub sections as thoughts occur. Sometimes these sub sections are general topics, while others are specific questions to be answered. The latter is better.
+ Always step away from your writing and relax, never go until your brain is fried -  this creates un conquerable writers block.
+ When you step away from your writing, always stop mid paragraph, mid sentance. This makes it easier to pick up next time. 
+ Always proofread, always revisit the introduction after the body is done. You will never know what you wrote until you actually write it.
+ Always write in single spacing, this allows for quick reference to previous paragrpahs and warrents longer sections.
+ Always write in a font that has distinct italics, bold and regular font faces. I use Cochin.
